content.text: Before the Knicks' game on Wednesday night, they vowed that Gilbert Arenas would not beat them with his scoring. He did not. He beat them by not taking the game-winning shot.  The Knicks were so concerned about stopping Arenas at the end of a tight game that they left Caron Butler open underneath the basket for a dunk that gave the Wizards a 99-98 victory at the Verizon Center.  ''It's obviously frustrating,'' Quentin Richardson said. ''You never want to lose that way. At the same time, we denied, denied and swarmed. They just made a great play at the end. They found probably the only open guy on the court.''  Coach Isiah Thomas was also dejected. He fielded a few questions from the news media before leaving the arena with a sour look on his face.  Arenas scored 16 points in what was a quiet night for him. He entered the game averaging 30.2 points, second most in the N.B.A, and he was coming off a 51-point performance against the Utah Jazz on Monday, when he made a game-winning 3-pointer.  Stephon Marbury deserved ample credit for his defense of Arenas, who made 4 of 14 shots and went 0 for 5 from beyond the 3-point arc. A double team -- and sometimes even a triple team -- never seemed far away when the ball arrived in Arenas's hands.  ''I've never really tried to beat double teams like that, because I know what kind of energy it takes to do that,'' Arenas said. ''I had to do that all through high school.''  Marbury has been playing exceptionally well on defense in recent weeks, which has sparked the Knicks (17-23) to four wins in their last six games.  ''I always play defense,'' Marbury said. ''I don't get enough credit for playing defense. I think this year it's just being talked about more because Isiah spoke about it and he said that I was playing the best defense of my career.''  The Knicks led twice in the closing moments. Marbury made a driving layup over Antawn Jamison to give the Knicks their first lead of the second half, 96-95, with 31 seconds left. After Jamison made a layup, the Knicks went to Jamal Crawford, who made the game-winning shot on Monday against the Sacramento Kings.  Crawford delivered again, making a runner in the lane after driving past Jamison. That gave the Knicks a 98-97 lead with 12.4 seconds left.  After a timeout, the Wizards (22-16) inbounded the ball to Arenas, and most of the 16,503 fans probably thought he would take the final shot. Arenas also made a game-winning 3-pointer against the Milwaukee Bucks earlier this month.  The Knicks closed in, as they had the entire game. Arenas passed to Jamison, who drove toward the basket before dishing off to DeShawn Stevenson on the left wing. Eddy Curry went out to cover Stevenson, who passed underneath to Butler.  ''That wasn't an easy pass that he made, but he got it through there,'' Curry said. ''You got to give him credit.''  Butler dunked with one hand to quash the Knicks' hopes of a thrilling comeback.  Crawford's desperation shot from near midcourt was on target but fell just short at the final buzzer.  ''We played a hard-fought game,'' Richardson said. ''We went blow for blow with them. Unfortunately they just got the last punch.''  The loss spoiled a fine offensive performance by Richardson, who finished with a game-high 35 points and made seven 3-pointers. He had 25 points in the first half.  The game was close for most of the first half, but the Wizards took a 14-point lead in the third quarter, when they went on a 19-3 spurt.  The Wizards led, 81-70, to start the fourth quarter, but the Knicks scored 8 consecutive points to cut the lead to 81-78.  They kept chipping away by going to Curry in the paint and threatening with Richardson from the perimeter. When Richardson made a 3-pointer with 2 minutes 45 seconds remaining, the Knicks cut the lead to 93-92.  With Arenas quiet, the Wizards went to Butler and Jamison. Butler led them with 27 points and Jamison added 21.  ''Everybody in the league, despite what anybody else says or writes, knows those two can play,'' Richardson said. ''But obviously Gilbert is the focal point.''  Last night it became apparent early on that he would not be the focal point. In the first quarter, Arenas mostly stood at the top of the key as his teammates looked for an open man. He took only 3 of the Wizards' first 17 shots.  ''We all knew what they were going to do before, and that's why we tried to keep four shooters out there when I was in,'' Arenas said.  Arenas began to look for his shot in the final minutes of the opening quarter. He finally got going when the Knicks handed him four consecutive free throws.  Thomas and Marbury were hit with technical fouls after arguing after Marbury was whistled for a touch foul as Arenas was shooting. He missed the shot but he made both technical free throws and both free throws that resulted from the initial foul.  Arenas was quiet for nearly the rest of the game, but just the threat of his scoring did the Knicks in.  ''We gave ourselves a chance to win,'' Jared Jeffries said. ''That's all you can really ask for.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Neutralizing Arenas Not Enough for Knicks

content.text: Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur has seen almost everything, but the 856th game of his N.H.L. career was different. On Saturday night, he could not recall allowing a game-tying goal with seven-tenths of a second left in regulation.  The Devils wound up beating the Islanders, 2-1, when center Scott Gomez knocked a shot past Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro with 1 minute 20 seconds remaining in overtime. The Devils' captain, Patrik Elias, set up the play, intercepting the puck and slipping a pass to Gomez.  It was a gorgeous goal, but it was not the most memorable one in a tense, thrilling duel between Brodeur and DiPietro. With DiPietro on the bench and the Devils' Brian Rafalski in the penalty box in the final moments of regulation, Islanders right wing Miroslav Satan scored to force overtime.  The sellout crowd of 16,234 at Nassau Coliseum roared. Brodeur lost what would have been his 8th shutout of the season and 88th of his career. He remembered allowing a similar goal at Montreal early in his career, but that was with two or three seconds left.  ''I don't think they had tenths of a second on the clock then,'' Brodeur said, smiling.  He could smile because the Devils (27-14-4) rescued him. John Madden, who scored what seemed to be the winning goal with 1:18 left in regulation, said the Devils chose to shrug off Satan's goal and play on.  ''I really like that about this team,'' he said. ''Nothing was said. We were ready to play overtime.''  In overtime, each team has four skaters, instead of the usual five, allowing Elias's creativity to become even more apparent. With Elias and Gomez forechecking fiercely, Elias guessed where the puck might be going. It ended up on his stick.  ''I really had nothing to shoot at, and I didn't see anything there,'' Elias said. ''Scotty got open, and it worked out.''  Elias tapped a short pass to Gomez, who rapped in his eighth goal of the season, and his second in two nights.  The Devils have won three straight against the Islanders (21-19-4), all in the last two weeks. Saturday's game had the feel of a playoff game, especially because the goalies stopped almost everything, sometimes acrobatically. Brodeur finished with 27 saves and DiPietro made 28.  ''It was just kind of playing chess,'' Islanders Coach Ted Nolan said.  Late in regulation, Madden took a drop pass from Sergei Brylin and fired a shot over DiPietro's glove that hit the top left corner of the net.  ''I just don't think he saw the shot,'' Madden said.  Midway through the third period, Brodeur tried leaping to snare a sailing puck before Satan got to it, but was knocked down instead. Play continued, and Brodeur made a sprawling pad save to keep the Islanders from scoring.  But with less than a second left, Brodeur did not move his left leg fast enough to stop a shot by Satan. The Devils knew better than to lose faith in him. ''You got the best goaltender in the world,'' Gomez said, ''so we thought, 'Let's win it in overtime.' ''  HOCKEY
content.title: Brodeur Wins Battle Of Goalies

content.text: Everything the Nets would like to be was wrapped into their 116-115 victory over the Utah Jazz on Monday night.  A team with a dominant star player: Vince Carter scored 33 points, including the winning 3-pointer at the buzzer.  A team with a balanced supporting cast: Eddie House had 19 points, and Antoine Wright and Marcus Williams added 12 each.  A team with resiliency: the Nets fought their way back from 13 points down in the second quarter and from 4 down with less than a minute and a half to play.  And then there was the performance of Jason Kidd, the face of the franchise, who had 22 points, 10 assists and 6 rebounds.  The Nets displayed those characteristics throughout their five-game Western trip, even if they finished with a 2-3 record. Perhaps that is why they seemed to be feeling confident as they headed back to New Jersey early Tuesday morning one game below .500 (22-23).  ''The big thing is that we're not going to quit,'' Kidd said after Monday night's game. ''We're going to play hard.''  If nothing else, this trip will be remembered because four of the five games were decided by a point. The Nets were three defensive stops short of having a nine-game winning streak. The Nets became the first team in N.B.A. history to have five of seven games decided by a point and only the fourth team to lose by a point three games in a row, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.  They lost each of the first three games of the trip -- against the Sacramento Kings, the Golden State Warriors and the Los Angeles Clippers -- by a point on their opponent's final shot.  In the fourth game, the Nets played stellar defense against the Denver Nuggets' Carmelo Anthony and Allen Iverson, two of the league's top three scorers. The Nets won that game, 112-102.  On Monday night, the Nets appeared to be out of it when they were down by 2 points with 5.9 seconds left and with the length of the court to go. But Carter jogged the ball up the court, used a screen from center Mikki Moore and drilled the winning shot from about 10 feet beyond the 3-point line.  ''Sometimes, what comes around goes around,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''And I think our guys deserve a great deal of credit for staying together and fighting the fight, so to speak, and not getting discouraged and not wilting and not letting circumstances determine their behavior.''  Perhaps more than anyone else, Carter seemed motivated by the Nets' early struggles on the trip.  Against the Kings, he scored a season-low 8 points and missed two crucial free throws down the stretch. Against the Warriors, he fouled Baron Davis on a 3-pointer late in the game and was later called for charging. Against the Clippers, he left Cuttino Mobley open for the winning 3-pointer.  After each of those games, Carter put much of the blame on himself and appeared uncharacteristically down.  But he made a renewed commitment to attacking the basket. In the final three games of the trip, Carter averaged 35.3 points and shot 66.1 percent from the field. He also averaged 12 free-throw attempts a game, evidence of his aggressiveness in the paint.  ''At the beginning of the trip, each individual had to step their game up, and I felt I had to do the same,'' Carter said Monday night. ''I felt that in the first three games, regardless of points, I didn't deliver because we didn't win the game. I'm just glad I could do it for my team.''  Carter is playing his best at a time when he is the subject of many trade rumors. Although the Nets' president, Rod Thorn, has said that players are worth more in trades when they are playing well, Carter might be making him think twice about any such decision.  The Nets also need Carter more than ever because they are without small forward Richard Jefferson, who missed the trip because of ankle surgery that could keep him out until early March. Jefferson was the Nets' second-leading scorer before he was injured.  Another good sign for the Nets was that their bench helped lift the burden of not having Jefferson. In each game, a different reserve stepped forward.  The rookie Hassan Adams took Jefferson's place in the starting lineup for the first three games, and Wright started the last two. Both were called on for their defense, and they delivered.  Wright was especially impressive. Before starting Saturday night's game against the Nuggets, he had not played in 12 of the previous 19 games. But he scored 11 points and slowed Anthony.  The reserve forward Bostjan Nachbar was averaging 17.7 points over a three-game stretch but became ill before the Jazz game and did not play. So House stepped in with his 19-point effort.  Moore had a fitting description for what these all-around contributions said about the Nets: ''We're a team.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets End 5-Game Trip By Making Their Point

content.text: With the anticipated return of Quentin Richardson and Nate Robinson for Wednesday's game against the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks will be at nearly full strength in a season in which they have lost players to injuries and suspensions and often played better while shorthanded.  The question at Monday's practice, as it has been at other times this season, was who would be in the starting lineup Wednesday. Coach Isiah Thomas said that for the immediate future he would stay with the same players who started the final two games of the Knicks' recent trip, lopsided victories against Portland and Seattle.  ''I don't want to prejudge or predetermine anything,'' Thomas said. ''I want to see where everybody's game is at.''  Stephon Marbury, Eddy Curry, Jared Jeffries, Channing Frye and Jamal Crawford started in the victories against Portland and Seattle. Of those five, only Marbury and Curry seem assured of remaining starters, particularly as Richardson weaves his way back into the team's nucleus.  Richardson began the season as the Knicks' starting small forward, because Jeffries was out with a wrist injury, but then missed 11 games with a bad back. Thomas said Richardson would get some time to ''knock the rust off'' his game, as would Robinson, who has finished serving a 10-game suspension for fighting.  Because Richardson is the team's best 3-point shooter and because he can also play shooting guard, he may eventually start in place of Crawford, who can score in bunches and has become adept at lobbing the ball inside to Curry for easy baskets. Richardson plays better defense than Crawford, and he also rebounds well.  During his injury layoff, Richardson was a visible cheerleader on the bench. In one memorable moment, he ran across the court in a suit to embrace Frye after Frye, a second-year forward, made a tying shot during the Knicks' three-overtime victory against Detroit last month. On Monday, he was the proper diplomat, saying, ''My job is to come in and fit in.''  In recent weeks, the most constant lineup question Thomas faced -- and one he will continue to be questioned about -- was why the second-year forward David Lee, who has turned into one of the N.B.A.'s most capable rebounders, was not starting every game. Thomas's response has been to say that he likes the way Lee is playing, but that he believes Lee provides the team with more of a spark when he comes off the bench.  That could change, as could the roles of other players.  ''We'll give it a couple of games and see how it goes,'' said Thomas, who added that he felt good coming off a pair of victories on the West Coast. ''Good and lucky.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Have a Surplus of Starters for a Change

content.text: For all the heartache the Nets suffered in the early part of this five-game Western trip, vindication came in the sweetest form Monday night.  Vince Carter made a 3-pointer from 31 feet at the buzzer to lift the Nets to a 116-115 victory against the Utah Jazz. His basket gave the Nets a 2-3 trip after they lost each of the first three games by a point on their opponent's final shot.  ''Sometimes what goes around comes around,'' Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''Our guys deserve a great deal of credit for staying together.''  The shot capped a magnificent 33-point night for Carter, who over the past three games has played like a superstar that one would be silly to trade. Carter scored 16 points in the fourth quarter.  He got the opportunity for the winner after Jazz point guard Deron Williams, who had been terrific all game and finished with 25 points, made 1 of 2 free throws.  Without any timeouts, the Nets had to go the length of the court in five seconds. Carter did just that, pulling up from way out. He was mauled by his teammates after the shot.  ''About midway, I felt it was going in,'' Carter said. ''it's just a great feeling to actually see it going in.''  The Nets also received a big game from Jason Kidd (22 points, 10 assists) and the reserve guard Eddie House, who scored 19 points.  Carter saved most of his aggression for a fourth quarter in which the teams traded baskets and played at a very quick pace.  During one stretch, Carter scored 11 consecutive points. Although it is difficult to take the ball from his hands when he is that hot, the approach might have become somewhat predictable.  On one possession in the final two minutes of the game, Carter tried to work off a screen from the top of the key. When he reached the lane, the Jazz clogged it and Carter passed the ball to Mikki Moore, who gave it back to Carter. With the shot clock running down, Carter had to settle for a long fadeaway jump shot that missed.  The Jazz marched down the court and Williams made a jumper to give the Jazz a 114-110 lead with 1 minute 22 seconds to play.  That was as far as the Nets would fall in the closing minutes.  The Nets (22-23) began this trip at .500 and with the news that one of their best players, small forward Richard Jefferson, could miss up to six weeks after ankle surgery.  Under those circumstances, the expectations might not have been very high.  But the manner in which the Nets lost the first three games of this trip, meant that they had a lot to play for in the final two games, namely mental stability.  That is exactly what they gave themselves.  ''It's just a relief for our team,'' Carter said. ''We've been on the other side of the ball.''  They had a terrific defensive performance against the Denver Nuggets, who boasted two of the league's three leading scorers -- Carmelo Anthony and Allen Iverson. The Nets also were able to see the super abilities of Carter that have been missing at times. He scored 40 points against the Nuggets.  In the Jazz, the Nets were facing one of the surprise teams in the league. Utah entered the night leading the Northwest Division and with the fourth-best record in the Western Conference.  Kidd kept the Nets in the game in the first half with 20 points, 5 assists and 5 rebounds.  Early in the second quarter, the Nets' defense went sour and the Jazz took advantage, scored on six of seven possessions in a stretch of about four minutes. Utah received a boost on the inside from power forward Paul Millsap, who had 6 points and 6 rebounds in 15 minutes in the first half.  Earlier in the day, Jazz Coach Jerry Sloan raved about Millsap's performance against the Hornets on Saturday night. In that game, Millsap scored 15 points and grabbed 17 rebounds, 10 on offense, even though not a single play was called for him. Millsap kept several possessions alive for the Jazz by muscling his way around the basket.  Williams's jump shot with 6:16 to play in the first half capped a 13-5 run that put Utah ahead by 13 points.  That is when Kidd took charge. He had two 3-pointers, two layups and a pair of free throws during a 24-14 run to close the first half and cut the deficit to 56-53.  Kidd received help in the third quarter from Carter, who scored only 4 points and reached the free throw line once in the first half, and the Nets were collectively hot on offense throughout the period. Carter scored 13 points on 4-of-7 shooting and the team shot 64.7 percent in the quarter.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Carter's Long 3 at Buzzer Sends Nets Home Happy

content.text: The 2006-7 season began as one long victory parade for the Maryland women's basketball team. After stunning the Duke Blue Devils in the N.C.A.A. championship game last April, the Terrapins have held the No. 1 spot in the national polls since November with an 18-game winning streak.  No team had challenged Maryland's perch until Saturday afternoon, when the Terrapins showed up at Cameron Indoor Stadium to meet Duke again.  And the rematch was no match. The Blue Devils outplayed Maryland in an 81-62 victory in front of a crowd of 9,314, a rare sellout for a women's game at Cameron.  ''I thought this game we were outworked, outhustled, outplayed, outcoached, you name it,'' Maryland Coach Brenda Frese said.  Duke guard Lindsey Harding drove the lane at will and finished with 28 points. The 6-foot-7 center Alison Bales had 18 points, 12 rebounds and 7 blocked shots.  Crystal Langhorne led Maryland (18-1) with 14 points.  It was the first meeting among the big three of the Atlantic Coast Conference. No. 1 Maryland, No. 2 North Carolina (19-0) and No. 3 Duke (18-0) have spent the season atop the polls and were the only three undefeated teams remaining going into Saturday's play.  The Terrapins, with all five starters back from last season's championship team, had been averaging 88.8 points a game, second best in the nation. But they faced a Duke defense that was allowing only 45.9 points a game, also second best in the nation. Duke held the Terrapins to 37.8 percent shooting from the field; they were 3 of 18 from 3-point range.  Maryland had taken an early lead before Duke built a 41-30 halftime advantage, led by Harding's 16 points. The Blue Devils, with three starters back from last season's team, knew better than to sit on that lead. Duke blew a 13-point lead to Maryland in the second half of the championship game before losing in overtime.  Duke Coach Gail Goestenkors said her halftime message was, ''I don't care about a lead, I have no interest in a lead right now, I don't want to secure a lead or hold onto a lead.''  Instead, the Blue Devils kept pushing and Maryland dropped behind by as many as 22 in the waning minutes. As the clock ticked down in the final minute, Duke guard Abby Waner allowed a smile to cross her face as she clapped her hands and motioned to the crowd. Goestenkors had ordered a distraught Waner to stay away from basketball for a month after the championship game loss.  ''One thing that Coach said to us yesterday that I think is really important is that with a win today, we don't win last year's national championship, that no matter what happened last year, we can't take it back,'' Waner said. ''So I'm more excited for this year. I think that this was our first big test, and we really proved ourselves, I feel like. But we have a lot farther to go.''  CONNECTICUT 76, SYRACUSE 45 -- The freshman center Tina Charles had 14 points, 19 rebounds and 5 blocks, and No. 7 Connecticut (14-1, 4-0 Big East) defeated visiting Syracuse (8-10, 2-3) in a tuneup before tomorrow's showdown with second-ranked North Carolina.  It was Charles's fifth double-double of the season, and her 19 rebounds were the most for a Connecticut player since Swin Cash had 20 against West Virginia in 2001. (AP)  STANFORD 63, WASHINGTON STATE 55 -- The freshman JJ Hones scored a season-high 17 points to help No. 10 Stanford (14-3, 7-0 Pac-10) send visiting Washington State (5-13, 1-7) to its seventh consecutive defeat. (AP)Texas A&M 60, Baylor 52 Takia Starks had 12 points and 11 rebounds, and No. 19 Texas A&M (12-3, 2-1 Big 12) defeated ninth-ranked Baylor (15-3, 2-2), the host Aggies' first victory against a top-10 team in five years. (AP)  MARQUETTE 76, VILLANOVA 70 -- Krystal Ellis scored 8 of her 21 points down the stretch to help No. 16 Marquette (16-2, 4-1 Big East) hold off visiting Villanova (7-10, 1-3) and bounce back from its loss at Pittsburgh on Tuesday that ended its 14-game winning streak. (AP)  COLLEGE BASKETBALL: WOMEN'S ROUNDUP
content.title: In Rematch of Championship, Maryland Is No Match for Duke

content.text: At the Final Four in Boston last April, the North Carolina women's basketball team saw a night full of promise dissolve into a disquieting mess.  The top-seeded Tar Heels lost in a semifinal to Maryland, which went on to win the national championship against Duke. North Carolina guard Ivory Latta said the flight home was filled with quiet tears.  Weeks and months passed, and Latta refused to watch the film from that game.  But on Friday, as the undefeated Tar Heels prepared for Sunday's game against Maryland, North Carolina Coach Sylvia Hatchell figured the time was right. Her players sat and stomached last season's end.  ''Man, it was depressing,'' Latta said. ''It was very hard to watch.''  But Latta said the film was also helpful. The players noticed simple mistakes they had made and vowed not to repeat them. At the Comcast Center on Sunday, the second-ranked Tar Heels took their long-awaited shot at the No. 3 Terrapins. This time, they walked off the court delighted, with an 84-71 victory that snapped Maryland's 19-game home winning streak before a crowd of 17,950 that was the largest to attend an Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season women's game.  ''Playing against North Carolina, playing against Duke, the revenge factor is so, so big right now,'' said Maryland forward Laura Harper, whose team lost to Duke, 81-62, on Jan. 13. ''They come ready to play us.''  For a time, North Carolina's victory looked as if it would come easily. The Tar Heels (23-0, 7-0) raced to a 20-point second-half lead behind the shooting of Latta, who made six 3-pointers and finished with 32 points.  But Maryland (21-2, 5-2) responded with a furious comeback that was led by the senior guard Shay Doron, who scored 13 of her 19 points in the second half. With 3 minutes 13 seconds left, Doron converted a 15-footer, pulling the Terrapins to 67-66.  ''She just kept putting them up, making shots and all,'' Hatchell said. ''But, you know, that's Maryland; I knew they could score like that.''  The Tar Heels, who entered the game as the nation's top-scoring team, can pounce quickly, too. They closed the game with a 17-5 run, and revenge was theirs.  When Maryland, Duke and North Carolina reached the Final Four last season, it was the first time a conference had placed three teams in the national semifinals; the A.C.C. had never sent more than one.  This season, the three A.C.C. powers have a combined record of 65-2, with the two losses coming within their impressive triumvirate. Maryland plays host to Duke on Feb. 18 but will not face North Carolina again in the regular season. North Carolina plays host to Duke on Feb. 8 before visiting the Blue Devils on Feb. 25.  Sunday's game became a sellout more than two weeks ago. The atmosphere and the national-television audience might have caused some early-game jitters for the Terrapins. Maryland missed 15 of its first 18 field-goal attempts and committed 10 turnovers in the first 10 minutes.  ''Anxiousness, nerves, whatever you want to call it,'' Maryland Coach Brenda Frese said. ''But at the same time, we have played on the biggest stage before.''  With 30 seconds remaining in the first half and North Carolina leading, 33-27, Maryland guard Kristi Toliver was hounded by two defenders as she struggled to bring the ball across midcourt. Frese stomped the floor and yelled to a referee, frustrated that a foul had not been called. She received a technical foul, and Latta made both free throws, giving the Tar Heels an 8-point halftime lead. Latta made four 3-pointers in the first 4:50 of the second half, putting North Carolina ahead by 20.  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: North Carolina Exacts Revenge While Remaining Undefeated

content.text: The Nets' margin of error over the past three games can essentially be measured in three possessions and 3 points. The resulting burden has manifested itself in blank stares, mumbled answers and an unusually quiet locker room.  When Cuttino Mobley hit a 3-pointer with six-tenths of a second remaining Thursday night in a game against the Los Angeles Clippers, it sealed a third consecutive 1-point defeat for the Nets. Each time, their opponent scored the winning shot on its final possession.  The Nets (20-23), who play Saturday night against the high-powered Nuggets in Denver, became the fourth team in N.B.A. history to lose three consecutive games by a point. With two games remaining on their five-game Western trip, the Nets are again looking for reasons to smile after their season appeared headed in a positive direction only a week ago.  ''Especially with the way that we're losing, it seems like if we can just make that one play, get that one loose ball, get that one close out on an open shot, maybe that'll change things for our favor,'' power forward Jason Collins said.  Last Saturday, the Nets beat the Orlando Magic to cap a four-game winning streak and return to .500 for the first time in two months. Two days later, Richard Jefferson, their starter at small forward, had arthroscopic surgery on his right ankle that could keep him out until early March.  That same night, for 47 minutes 49 seconds against the Kings in Sacramento, the Nets looked as if they would overcome the loss of Jefferson and secure one of their biggest victories of the season. But then their bizarre stretch of tough luck and late-game mistakes began.  The Kings, who overcame a 20-point third-quarter deficit, went to point guard Mike Bibby on their final possession. Bibby had taken over the game in the fourth quarter, but he missed a shot from the top of the key. Kings forward Brad Miller came down with the rebound and missed a layup attempt. The ball was tipped back out to Bibby, who was wide open at the top of the key. His shot with 10.3 seconds remaining gave the Kings an 88-87 victory.  ''We shouldn't have put ourselves in that position, being up by 20 points,'' Nets point guard Jason Kidd said after the game.  Against the Golden State Warriors on Wednesday night, the Nets were ahead by 109-108 when forward Bostjan Nachbar missed a shot from the corner with just over five seconds remaining. The Warriors' Baron Davis raced the ball upcourt and found guard Monta Ellis, who hit a shot from the wing at the buzzer.  On Thursday, the Nets took a 101-99 lead with 1:07 to play, but the Clippers got their chance after calling a timeout with eight seconds left.  Point guard Sam Cassell, who was guarded by the Nets rookie Marcus Williams, dribbled around a screen at the top of the key and streaked down the right edge of the lane. As Cassell got past Williams, Vince Carter came over to double-team, leaving Mobley open behind the 3-point line. Cassell passed to Mobley; Carter could only watch as Mobley hit the winner.  That final play seemed to weigh most heavily on Carter, despite his 33 points in one of his best offensive performances of the season.  ''I screwed it up,'' he said. ''I feel bad for it.''  Those three failed defensive stops are the difference between a seven-game winning streak and a three-game skid for the Nets. Each defeat has seemed to deflate them even more. Heartbreakers do not normally happen this often and this close together.  The Nets' previous three 1-point losses were spread over 21 months and three seasons.  ''You put your heart and soul as a player and coach into this,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said after the loss to the Clippers. ''This hurts. Every loss hurts and the fact that you put all three together, it really hurts you.''  Frank was speechless at times during his postgame news conference Thursday night. Even after defeats, the Nets players usually find something to joke or smile about in the locker room after the game. Not much of that was going on after the game against the Clippers.  Still, the Nets were trying to find a silver lining to what has happened over the past few days, perhaps a means of keeping their psyches straight as they enter what might be the most difficult games of this trip.  ''When you give yourself a chance to win, that's all you can ask for,'' Kidd said. ''It's not like we're getting blasted by 20 and you're trying to search for what we need to do.''  The Nets may know their formula for success. Now they have to figure out how to stick to it for a full 48 minutes.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: In Last Three Games, Nets Are Missing the Point

content.text: The Los Angeles Lakers missed Kobe Bryant's other-worldliness, fans at Madison Square Garden missed his showmanship and the Knicks, for once, did not miss the golden opportunity that was handed to them.  They rode Eddy Curry's offense, enjoyed a surprising resurgence by Jared Jeffries and beat back the Lakers for a 99-94 victory last night. With Bryant yanked from the stage by a league suspension, the evening lacked pyrotechnics, star quality and drama.  But for those who came to see the Knicks (20-27) claim a rare victory against an elite team, the night ended with some satisfaction. All five starters scored in double figures, led by Curry's 27 points. Jeffries, who started for the injured Quentin Richardson, filled up the box score and had a game-clinching block with 12.1 seconds left to play.  The Knicks, who had beaten just one team with a winning record in the past month, held on despite losing a 9-point lead in the first half and a 10-point lead in the fourth quarter.  ''You're never going to blow them out,'' Coach Isiah Thomas said. ''They're a team with a great coach, who understands how to manipulate a game and keep his team close.''  Thomas praised the Lakers (27-18) at length for their resiliency and, with a smile, concluded: ''But I'm glad Kobe didn't play. I'm really happy he didn't play.''  Twice in the previous eight days, the Knicks lost to teams missing their star players -- in Milwaukee (Michael Redd) and Miami (Dwyane Wade and Shaquille O'Neal). The Lakers, who were also missing the starters Luke Walton and Kwame Brown, kept the game close behind Lamar Odom (25 points and 9 rebounds).  Odom and Vladimir Radmanovic made 3-pointers to spark a late rally, knocking the deficit down to 96-94 with 45.8 seconds left. Curry hit two free throws to extend the lead to 4 points. He finished 9 for 12 from the foul line -- no small thing, given his own struggles and Thomas's recent rant about the Knicks' poor foul shooting. The Knicks shot free throws for an hour on Monday.  ''It meant a lot,'' Curry said of his late free throws, ''because I know how important free throws are to this team and especially to Coach.''  After Curry's free throws, the Lakers' Maurice Evans had a 3-pointer rattle out of the rim, but they still had a chance after Jamal Crawford ran (or was bumped) out of bounds for a turnover. But Jeffries reached out and blocked a 3-point try by Brian Cook in the corner, handing the Lakers their first three-game losing streak of the season.  Only a week ago, Jeffries was benched by Thomas and had his playing time slashed. Jeffries had been ineffective for weeks. But with Richardson nursing a sprained elbow, Thomas turned back to Jeffries, who responded with his best game in a month -- 14 points, 7 rebounds, 4 assists, 2 steals, 2 blocked shots and 1 turnover in 32 minutes.  ''I thought the way he competed was impressive, considering the ups and downs that he's been having,'' Thomas said.  Booed during pregame introductions, Jeffries was cheered for his hustle several times throughout the night.  ''Those kind of things are why I'm here,'' said Jeffries.  Stephon Marbury scored 22 points but aggravated his sore left knee and sat out the last 35.2 seconds. He landed awkwardly after leaping to grab an errant inbounds pass from Jeffries.  Marbury recently sat out a game to rest the knee but said he would play tonight in Charlotte.  ''I just landed funny,'' he said. ''I'm all right.''  The chance to see Bryant had drawn a larger-than-usual cadre of celebrities, from the comedian Jon Stewart to the rapper Eve, the singer Nick Lachey and the real-estate mogul Donald Trump.  Bryant was suspended earlier in the day, for elbowing San Antonio's Manu Ginóbili in the face Sunday during a loss to the Spurs. Fans booed loudly when the suspension was announced before tip-off -- an unheard-of reaction, given that the punishment was for an opponent.  Thomas did not share their disappointment.  ''I'm a big fan of Kobe and I like him personally,'' Thomas said. ''You hate to see anyone suspended. But I don't want to face him, I don't want to face Shaq, I don't want to face Vince Carter, I don't want to face any of the best players in the league, because I know what they're capable of.''  What about the fans, who were denied their only chance to see Bryant play here this season?  ''Video games, television, catch him the next time,'' Thomas said with a laugh. ''I'm sure they'll have a couple of national television games, and all of New York can tune in and watch him.''  REBOUNDS  Quentin Richardson said that his right elbow injury was not serious and that he hoped to return to the lineup tonight in Charlotte. Richardson sprained the elbow in a practice last week and scored 6 points over his next three games, going 3 for 14 from the field. ''It just wasn't feeling that good,'' said Richardson, who is averaging 13.3 points. Richardson had a bandage on the elbow when he spoke with reporters, but he said he had not received an injection or had the elbow drained. ''It got scratched,'' he said.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Inject The Garden With a Buzz And a Win

content.text: The Nets squandered double-digit leads in the fourth quarter and lost each of their first two games of their trip out West, a reflection of their inability to maintain a steady course this season.  The letdowns, 1-point defeats to the Sacramento Kings on Monday night and the Golden State Warriors on Wednesday night, came on the heels of a four-game winning streak that had the Nets at .500 for the first time in two months. They have followed each apparent turning point this season with a misstep.  With their season past the midway point, the Nets (20-22) were still trying for their first road victory against a Western Conference opponent when they played the Los Angeles Clippers (20-21) on Thursday night.  After the game against the Warriors, ''the mood was not good,'' Rod Thorn, the Nets' president, said Thursday morning. ''If you're a competitor, as a player or as a coach, you're very upset about that, about losing two games like that, games that you had in hand.''  Perhaps most disheartening for the Nets is that their five-game trip was getting more difficult. They play the Denver Nuggets on Saturday night and the Utah Jazz on Monday.  ''Virtually every game, we're playing a better team,'' Thorn said. ''We've got our work cut out for us.''  Against the Kings, the Nets held a 20-point lead in the third quarter, only to have it evaporate at the hands of Sacramento point guard Mike Bibby, who capped a strong fourth quarter by making the winning shot with 10 seconds remaining.  ''We just quit playing,'' Thorn said. ''We just stood around in the fourth quarter.''  The Nets led the Warriors by 11 points with a little more than four minutes remaining, but Golden State finished the game on a 17-5 run, capped by guard Monta Ellis hitting the winner at the buzzer. It was the seventh time this season the Nets had lost after squandering a double-digit lead.  ''It is hard,'' Nets forward Bostjan Nachbar said after the game. ''It is not easy. We had both games won. We thought we were the better team, at least most of the game. We lost the game down the stretch, and the next couple games will show how tough we are.''  The Nets' grit will have to start with their two stars, Jason Kidd and Vince Carter. That is especially true with their third top-flight player, Richard Jefferson, out for about six weeks after he had arthroscopic surgery on his right ankle Monday.  Kidd has been stellar all season, playing some of the best basketball of his career, but he had eight turnovers against the Warriors.  Carter, after leading by 214,000 votes the last time they were counted, was surpassed in the All-Star voting by the Washington Wizards' Gilbert Arenas for an Eastern Conference starting spot Thursday. Arenas beat out Carter by 3,010 votes, the smallest margin in 17 years. Carter has been voted a starter six times.  Before Thursday night's game, Carter pretended to have thought he had beaten out Arenas. After sarcastically acting as if his feelings were hurt, Carter said he would not be disappointed to go the game as a reserve.  ''It's still an honor to be involved in it,'' he said.  For now, Carter has more pressing things to think about. He scored only 8 points against the Kings. Despite having 23 points and a career-high 13 assists against the Warriors, he did not dominate down the stretch.  The injuries to Jefferson and center Nenad Krstic, who is out for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament, have probably affected Carter more than any other player because he faces more double-teams.  As the Nets have struggled this season, Carter has seemed to be the most likely candidate for a trade if Thorn chooses to make drastic changes. Carter can opt out of his contract at the end of the season, meaning the Nets may try to get someone in return for him if they feel he may leave.  But with the Nets' recent success -- they had won 9 of 11 games before losing to the Kings and the Warriors -- much of the trade talk seemed to have settled.  The Nets' ability to make any significant trades by the Feb. 22 deadline could be hampered by the fact that two of their biggest assets, Jefferson and Krstic, are injured.  ''When you're talking about trading, you trade from assets,'' Thorn said. ''If you don't have a lot of assets to trade, it's difficult to make anything but a minor trade.''  BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Take Two Steps Back After a Big Step Forward

content.text: Maurice Greene and Gail Devers, two Americans who have won Olympic and world championships, were added yesterday to the field for the 100th annual Millrose Games Feb. 2 in Madison Square Garden. Greene, 32, will run in the men's 60-meter dash and Devers, 40, in the women's 60-meter hurdles.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: GREENE AND DEVERS JOIN MILLROSE FIELD

content.text: The Nets have won four of five games, they are back atop the Atlantic Division and Vince Carter scored 32 points against his former team.  The Nets (15-19) beat the Toronto Raptors, 101-86, at Continental Arena Tuesday night, and got a fine effort from Jason Kidd, who fell two rebounds short of a triple-double, with 10 points and 14 assists.  Earlier in the day, Kidd was the focus of events beyond the court after filing for divorce from his wife, Joumana. ''There are really no distractions,'' he said after the game. ''This is my job, this is my livelihood. So anything personal stays personal and anything that's related to my job stays within my job.''  The Nets moved a half game ahead of the Raptors (15-20) for first place in the Atlantic Division, in which all five teams have losing records.  When the season started last November, not too many people would have picked this game to be a division battle. The Nets have won four of the last five division titles, and the Raptors have a young team that has not accomplished much since Carter left Toronto more than two years ago.  But the Raptors have had some impressive performances against top-flight teams this season, including a 2-point loss to the Phoenix Suns last week. Their future could be bright in part because of their 7-foot rookie forward, Andrea Bargnani, who hit 4 of 7 shots from 3-point range and led the Raptors with 22 points.  Although Bargnani got his looks, the Nets held forward Chris Bosh, the Raptors' best player, to 12 points. Bosh was playing in only his fourth game after missing 12 with a bruised bone in his right foot. The Nets also held Toronto's starting point guard, T. J. Ford, scoreless on 0-for-8 shooting from the field.  Nets forward Mikki Moore, who scored 12 points and had 8 rebounds, said stopping Bosh was a team effort.  ''Everybody shrunk the floor,'' he said. ''We talked. We communicated.''  The all-around effort, especially on defense, has often been absent for the Nets this season, and it has been one of the biggest culprits in their lackadaisical start.  The Nets' fortitude was most evident in the way they sprang back from what could have been a game-changing run by the Raptors.  After the Nets took a 15-0 lead to start the game, the Raptors pulled ahead with a 22-2 run that spanned parts of the first and second quarters and lasted nearly eight minutes. The Nets missed 10 of 11 shots during the stretch and had 6 turnovers.  The Nets answered by giving up only 38 points in the second half. They paid more attention to Bargnani, the first pick in last year's draft, and held him to 6 points after halftime.  ''We're not exactly where we want to be,'' said Nets forward Richard Jefferson, who scored 21 points. ''We understand now that we've dug ourselves a hole. It's a matter now of playing above and beyond to get out of the hole. This was a step in the right direction.''  Carter seemed intent on setting the tone against the team he played with for more than six seasons. The last time the Nets played the Raptors in Toronto, Carter scored only 12 points in a Nets loss. He had 14 points in the first quarter Tuesday night.  Perhaps Carter came out with a message from the Nets power forward Cliff Robinson in mind. Before the game, Carter said, Robinson told the team that it needed to bounce back from a defeat, much the way it did last season. The Nets were coming off a loss to the Cavaliers in Cleveland on Saturday night.  ''By him saying that, it kind of put something in the minds of the guys who are here,'' Carter said. ''We really game out with guns blazing.''  REBOUNDS  Cliff Robinson did not play in the second half because of a back strain that he sustained while bending over earlier in the day. Robinson, who was playing in only his third game after a month and a half absence because of an injured left knee, said he should be ready for Thursday night's game against the Bulls.  The Nets' rookie power forward Josh Boone, who did not play Saturday night after incurring his third migraine headache in three months, said he would have a precautionary magnetic resonance imaging exam in a few weeks.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Overcome Their Off-Court Distractions

content.text: The Nets will be without Richard Jefferson, their starting small forward, for about six weeks after he has arthroscopic surgery today to remove loose fragments from his right ankle.  Jefferson is the team's second-leading scorer, and the news comes during one of the Nets' most promising stretches of the season. They beat the Orlando Magic on Saturday night for their ninth victory in 11 games and got back to .500 for the first time in two months.  The Nets (20-20) start a five-game trip to the West on Monday night with a game against the Kings in Sacramento. The trip could be an indicator of what direction the Nets, the leaders of the Atlantic Division, will take for the remainder of the season.  Jefferson, who has been bothered by ankle problems all season, chose to have the surgery now because his ankle was not getting better, said Rod Thorn, the Nets' president. Jefferson took two cortisone shots earlier this season, and Thorn said they were not working. Having the surgery now avoids the possibility of Jefferson's ankle becoming so bad that he would have to miss the rest of the season.  ''He's just not able to do the type things that he can do,'' Thorn said during a telephone interview yesterday. ''He's playing about 50, 55 percent. It's tough for him. He's a young guy, still in the early part of his career. It's mentally a tough situation.''  If Jefferson recovers in six weeks, he should be back by early March, when the Nets have a six-game trip.  Coach Lawrence Frank said his team needed to find a way to cope with Jefferson's absence.  ''Injuries happen throughout the course of the season, so regardless of how you're playing, where you're playing, that's the unfortunate reality of pro sports,'' he said by telephone.  Regardless of who plays in place of Jefferson, Frank added, ''We understand we have to be consistent.''  Jefferson missed five games early in the season after rolling his left ankle, and the second-year swingman Antoine Wright started in his place.  But Wright has fallen out of the rotation and Frank said he was not sure who would replace Jefferson. Frank said matchups could dictate his starting lineup, which may change from game to game.  Jefferson was averaging 16.1 points, 4.5 rebounds and 2.9 assists this season, all below his career averages. But he seemed to be battling through the pain and was showing flashes of his usual explosiveness. In a victory against the Knicks on Friday night, he scored 21 points.  Many credited Jefferson's improved play at times for the team's turnaround from an 11-18 record.  Jefferson's problems date to last season's playoffs, when he sprained his right ankle in the second round against the Miami Heat. He tweaked the ankle again in the off-season. The problems with the ankle resurfaced during a game against the Milwaukee Bucks in mid-December. Jefferson sat out the second half of that game because it was sore, and he missed the next game, at Toronto.  Jefferson, 26, has always prided himself on his ability to play through pain, and the nagging injury has frustrated him.  Last month, Jefferson said of his statistics: ''We're looking at some of the lows of my career. It's not acceptable.''  And after Saturday night's game, Jefferson dismissed a question about whether he would make the trip, saying: ''You're not asking me any questions about this. Come on, guys.''  Thorn said he did not believe that Jefferson's ankle problems would threaten his career.  Jefferson will be the fifth Nets player to have surgery this season. The most serious injury has been to their starting center, Nenad Krstic, who will miss the rest of the season after tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in late December. Krstic was the Nets' second-leading scorer at the time of his injury.  ''You can't lose players like Richard now, on top of Nenad,'' Thorn said. ''It's going to affect your team, obviously. We are just coming into one of the most difficult periods of our schedule. The players are going to have to play an increased role.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Will Lose Jefferson for 6 Weeks

content.text: A young, rebuilding Rutgers team might have learned something Wednesday night. It probably is not going to win a jump-shooting contest.  Against the Syracuse zone defense, Rutgers could do little else but shoot long-range jumpers, a strategy that failed. Hitting 18 of 61 shots (29.5 percent) from the field and scoring just 20 points in the paint, the Scarlet Knights were no match for Syracuse, losing by 68-58.  Only the reserve guard Courtney Nelson, who led Rutgers with 14 points, seemed to be in any rhythm for the Scarlet Knights (8-8, 1-2 Big East). But he made only 3 of 9 field-goal attempts.  ''I thought we did a good job of getting the ball inside, but, of course, any time you see a zone you've got to make shots,'' Rutgers Coach Fred Hill said. ''There are a lot of different ways to attack a zone, but you've got to make shots to loosen things up a bit. We got some great looks, but they didn't go down.''  The Orange (13-4, 2-1 Big East) offered a far more diverse attack. Shooting 46.9 percent, they got solid interior play from Darryl Watkins (9 points, 10 rebounds) and Demetris Nichols (12 points, 7 rebounds), as well as good perimeter shooting from guard Eric Devendorf, who led all scorers with 19 points.  ''These games are made for Eric,'' Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said. ''Teams will go way out with their defense. That creates space for him to get to the basket.''  The Orange also helped itself at the free-throw line, making 18 of 21 attempts.  Rutgers was cold throughout, making 9 of 32 field-goal attempts during an opening half that ended with Syracuse leading, 28-25. Ten Syracuse turnovers helped Rutgers stay close.  The Orange got an immediate lift from an unlikely source. Guard Andy Rautins, who was averaging 5 points a game, scored 9 of Syracuse's first 11 points. He did not score again.  Syracuse took control early in the second half. A dunk by Nichols with 16 minutes 4 seconds left extended the lead to 39-30, and for Rutgers, it would only get worse. When Roberts dunked with 4:55 to go, the Orange had a 60-43 lead. Rutgers cut the deficit in the closing minutes, and when Marquis Webb scored on a putback with 54.4 seconds left, the lead was 6 points. Nichols responded by making a pair of free throws, and seconds later, Devendorf sealed the game by making two more free throws.  ''The shots weren't falling,'' Rutgers forward J. R. Inman said. ''It just wasn't outside. We were missing midrange and a lot of shots we usually hit. It was an adjustment for us. We haven't played a team that big down low. When you see a zone and with a lot of big, athletic guys, it's hard to adjust.''  The loss came just four days after Rutgers played what might have been its best game of the season, a 54-42 victory at Cincinnati. The 42 points were the fewest scored against Rutgers by a Big East opponent.  The Orange have beaten Rutgers six straight times, which includes an 86-84 overtime victory last season at the Carrier Dome. Three of Syracuse's four losses have come against teams that were ranked at the time.  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: Rutgers Can't Get Shots to Drop Against Tough Syracuse Defense

content.text: On the play that essentially decided the game, Knicks guard Stephon Marbury did everything right defensively. He stepped around a high screen set by Ruben Patterson, Milwaukee's muscular forward, and forced the right-handed guard Mo Williams to dribble left.  But Williams, who had missed the previous nine games with a sprained left shoulder, made an off-balance 20-footer Sunday to give the Bucks a 4-point lead with 3.1 seconds to play. That basket, and a foul shot that Williams was actually trying to miss, enabled the Bucks to overcome 17 fourth-quarter points from Jamal Crawford and hold off the Knicks, 107-105, at the Bradley Center.  ''He made a good shot,'' Marbury said of Williams. ''I wouldn't call it a lucky shot.''  Had the Knicks defended the first 47 minutes 50 seconds as well as Marbury did on that play, the struggling Bucks might not have broken their six-game losing streak, and Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas might not have turned his postgame news conference into a lamentation on his team's failure to make free throws.  The Knicks finished 14 of 24 from the line (58.3 percent) after a 10-for-20 start. The numbers 14 and 24 remained on the locker room dry erase board long after Thomas pulled on his dark wool overcoat and headed for the team bus.  ''Our inability to convert when we get to the foul line is killing us right now, and all season,'' Thomas said.  Center Eddy Curry, who shot 6 for 9 and had 15 points in his return from a strained left calf muscle, and the backup forward David Lee (19 points, 14 rebounds) gave the Knicks a strong presence inside.  But Thomas and his players used words like ''strange'' and ''weird'' to describe a game that the Knicks, who gave up too many layups and easy baskets inside, nearly pulled out.  ''It was definitely a strange game from the beginning,'' Curry said. ''It wasn't one of those games where we were clicking early and rode a wave the whole game.''  The Knicks' performance mirrored that of Crawford, who was ineffective until the final quarter.  Coming off his career-high 52 points against Miami on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, Crawford did not touch the ball the first four minutes as the Knicks worked it inside to Curry. Then he missed his first six shots.  The Knicks trailed by as many as 11 before Crawford scored his first basket, a pumping layup from the right with 1 minute 12 seconds left in the first half.  ''I think the first game after a game like that is probably the hardest,'' Crawford said, referring to his big night. ''By my teammates kept encouraging me.''  When the fourth quarter began, the Knicks trailed, 78-69, and Crawford was 3 of 13 from the field. But over the next 10 minutes, he and the rookie reserve forward Renaldo Balkman led the Knicks back.  Crawford scored 14 points, including two 3-pointers, while Balkman added 8 points inside and a block. Then, two foul shots and a 3-pointer by Marbury cut the Bucks' lead to 102-100 with a minute to play.  But Williams, who finished with 30 points and 10 assists, proved too tough. He had a hand in Milwaukee's final 11 points. Over the last 4:03, Williams hit three jumpers and one free throw and had two assists.  Williams and Marbury exchanged baskets before Williams sank the critical 20-footer. The Knicks called timeout to advance the ball to the forecourt, where Mardy Collins inbounded to Crawford, who made a quick catch-and-shoot 3-pointer. Even though no Knick touched the ball before Crawford, the game clock ran down to 0.8 from 3.1.  Thomas argued that the play could not have taken that much time, but the officials let it stand.  ''It was their call,'' Thomas said.  Crawford fouled Williams on the inbounds play, leaving four-tenths of a second left.  Then, more weirdness. Williams missed the first of two free throws. On the second, he stepped to the left side of the foul line and tried bank the ball off the rim to keep play alive and run out the clock. Instead, he swished it.  ''I guess I'm too good of a free-throw shooter,'' Williams said, laughing.  After another Knicks timeout, Crawford shot an air ball on a turnaround 3-point attempt from the left corner. The shot would not have counted because Crawford stepped on the sideline as he spun.  ''I was just trying to rush to get it up there,'' Crawford said.  Marbury was left to explain how the Knicks, after routing the Heat with Dwyane Wade and Shaquille O'Neal, could lose to an undersized Milwaukee team without its leading scorer, Michael Redd (strained left patellar tendon). The Bucks had been 0-4 at the Bradley Center in January after going 7-0 in December.  ''We have to come out more prepared at the beginning of the game to make the plays, so we don't put ourselves in these situations,'' Marbury said.  REBOUNDS  Guard NATE ROBINSON had a halfcourt 3-point basket at the end of the first quarter disallowed on video review, because the clock showed time had expired before the ball left his hands. Undaunted, Robinson tried again just before halftime and made it from three-quarters court, easily beating the buzzer.  The Knicks deactivated KELVIN CATO to activate EDDY CURRY.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Clock Expires As Comeback By Knicks Falls Short

content.text: The Miami Heat defeated the Knicks handily Monday without Shaquille O'Neal and Dwyane Wade. On Friday, the teams will meet again, but this time it may be the Knicks who are short-handed.  Guard Stephon Marbury, who missed Wednesday's game against the Phoenix Suns with a knee injury, said Thursday that he was fit to play. But Coach Isiah Thomas said that center Eddy Curry, the Knicks' leading scorer, was questionable. Curry, who strained his left calf muscle during the second half Wednesday, did not practice Thursday.  One Knicks player whose status was not ambiguous was Jared Jeffries, an ineffective starter who played 9 minutes 14 seconds in the past two games. Jeffries, a forward, received a vote of confidence from Thomas, who did not discuss potential lineups other than to say that Jeffries would start against the Heat.  ''He's definitely got to play a little better than what he's playing,'' Thomas said. ''We'll stick with him, and hopefully he'll come out of it. And if not, we have some guys on the bench that are eager to play.''  The Knicks (18-26) will have their hands full even if Curry and Marbury are healthy and Jeffries produces. The Heat defeated them Monday in Miami, 101-83, without O'Neal and Wade, its two best players. If the Knicks lose, they will fall to a season-worst nine games below .500.  O'Neal and Wade returned Wednesday as the Heat (19-23) lost to the Indiana Pacers in overtime, 96-94. Wade was coming off a sprained ankle, and O'Neal had missed the previous 35 games while recovering from knee surgery. O'Neal, who came off the bench and played 14 minutes against the Pacers, will presumably play more against the Knicks.  Asked how effective he thought O'Neal would be Friday, Thomas pointed to the doorway leading to the trainer's room. ''When he stands in that door, he takes up the whole door,'' Thomas said. ''And when he stands in front of somebody, you can't see them. He's a big man, and that's the Shaq effect. It has nothing to do with points and rebounds.''  Defense might not be Curry's specialty, but he seems to be the natural matchup against O'Neal. If Curry is unable to play, it is not clear how Thomas will respond.  ''It would be a huge loss, but we'll get by,'' Thomas said.  Channing Frye would probably join Jeffries at forward. Thomas could go with a big frontcourt by inserting the seldom-used Jerome James or Kelvin Cato at center. Or he could use a smaller frontcourt and have the 6-foot-9 David Lee defend O'Neal. Lee would surrender four inches to O'Neal, but he is bulkier than Frye or Jeffries. The 6-7 Malik Rose, who sometimes guarded O'Neal when he played for the San Antonio Spurs, is another option.  The Knicks may simply rotate several players on O'Neal, spreading their fouls. They may try to wear him down on offense, too.  ''He's coming off an injury, so hopefully we can get out and push the ball in transition and make him run up and down the court,'' Jeffries said.  Jeffries missed 26 of the Knicks' first 30 games because of injury or suspension. He came to the Knicks in the off-season with a reputation as a defensive stopper. But his play this season has been as unsightly as his jump shot.  After practice Thursday, Jeffries said he needed to play with more confidence, an observation he has made before.  ''Whenever I play well, coaches play me,'' Jeffries said.  He added, referring to Thomas: ''So I haven't played well, and really right now he has no reason to play me. I put myself in this position.''  A return to form by Jeffries will be needed, especially if Curry is unavailable. Curry, who has started all 44 games and has been the focal point of the Knicks' offense, had his way inside against the Suns before feeling tightness in his calf during the third quarter. He was injured when he planted his left foot in the opening minutes of the fourth quarter. Curry, who left the game for good, was listed as questionable for Friday.  ''It's kind of hard to gauge it, being I didn't practice,'' said Curry, who initially feared the injury might cost him 15 to 20 games. ''It's kind of painful right now when I step. Try to loosen it up and see what happens.''  Marbury, who was listed as probable, seemed more certain of his status, though Thomas said he would be evaluated again Friday. If healthy, Marbury would probably join Quentin Richardson in the backcourt. Marbury has been playing with pain in his left knee since Dec. 15.  ''I worked out a little bit, did some running,'' Marbury said. ''I felt pretty good.'' He added: ''Yes, I'm playing tomorrow.''  BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Face Another Loss as Heat's Stars Return

content.text: Seton Hall announced a heaping portion of bad news before Friday night's game against Georgetown. Its starting center and tallest player, the 6-foot-10 Grant Billmeier, was lost for the season.  The Pirates never seemed to rebound -- literally and figuratively.  Georgetown raced to an early lead and it dominated the boards in a 74-58 victory at Continental Arena.  ''I've been a head coach eight years, and I've never seen a stat where we got beat on the boards, 39 to 11,'' Seton Hall Coach Bobby Gonzalez said. ''We had one defensive rebound at halftime.''  It got worse in the second half, when the Pirates (11-7, 3-3 Big East) managed only four rebounds.  Georgetown (13-5, 3-2) had a significant height advantage. It started three players who were 6-8 or taller, including the 7-2 center Roy Hibbert. Seton Hall's tallest starter was Stan Gaines, who was listed at 6-7.  Billmeier, a tri-captain, tore his left anterior cruciate ligament while playing defense during the opening minutes of Wednesday's 69-68 victory against Providence. He started 14 times this season and averaged 3.4 points and 3.4 rebounds a game.  ''He gives you 15, 20 minutes a night,'' Gonzalez said of Billmeier. ''He changes the rotation, he is a senior, he does play hard. He's a great energy guy. And so now you have one less body. It's a small team getting smaller.''  John Garcia, at 6-9, became Seton Hall's tallest player. He came off the bench to grab three rebounds, which tied Paul Gause for the team high. Georgetown, which had been ranked eighth in the preseason but has fizzled out of the Top 25, had six players with at least three rebounds. DaJuan Summers had a game-high 10 rebounds and 17 points.  ''If I'm going to give this team anything, it's rebounds,'' Garcia said. ''I'm not going to make excuses.''  Gonzalez hinted at an excuse anyway, saying that Seton Hall was fatigued from playing four games in nine days. And when the Hoyas raced to a 10-0 lead after just 2 minutes 10 seconds, the Pirates were not able to recover. They trailed, 34-21, at halftime and fell behind by as many as 20 points late in the game.  Jonathan Wallace led Georgetown with a career-high 21 points, and he helped break down Seton Hall's full-court pressure and zone defense.  ''We handled their pressure better than I anticipated,'' Georgetown Coach John Thompson III said. ''Our guys were very poised and pretty attentive and seeing when their teammates were in trouble.''  Brian Laing scored a team-high 19 points for the Pirates. But like five of his teammates, he had no rebounds.  ''We just didn't have the bodies and the energy and the juice to play a team like Georgetown tonight,'' Gonzalez said. ''It's just that simple.''  LOYOLA, MD. 62, ST. PETER'S 55 -- Michael Tuck made four free throws in the final 11 seconds and finished with 14 points as Loyola of Maryland beat host Saint Peter's.  Gerald Brown and Marquis Sullivan also scored 14 points each for the Greyhounds (10-7, 6-1 Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference), and Brett Harvey had a game-high eight assists.  Akeem Gooding had 16 points and 6 rebounds -- both game highs -- to lead the Peacocks (3-15, 1-7), who made just 37 percent of their shots. Kevin Spann added 12 points, and Todd Sowell finished with 11 and Raul Orta had 10.  Loyola led for most of the game but had trouble putting away the Peacocks, who rallied late and tied the score at 55-55 when Brandon Brock hit a jumper with 56 seconds left.  But the Greyhounds closed the game with a 7-0 run keyed by Tuck's free throws. (AP)  FAIRFIELD 72, SIENA 67 -- Michael Van Schaick scored 27 points to lead Fairfield in a victory against host Siena.  Fairfield (5-15, 3-5 MAAC) rallied from a 9-point deficit with 5:32 remaining for the victory.  Van Schaick tied the score at 66-66 with his fifth 3-pointer of the game with a minute left.  After Kenny Hasbrouck missed a jumper for Siena, Van Schaick was fouled with 30 seconds left and converted both free throws.  Siena (9-8, 5-3) had a chance to tie, but David Ryan missed the first of two free throws with 22 seconds left.  After Jonathan Han made two free throws to put Fairfield up, 70-67, with 16 seconds to go, the Saints failed to get a shot off.  Hasbrouck led the Saints with 23 points, and Michael Haddix had 14 points and 14 rebounds.  Siena shot 46 percent from the field and 38 percent from 3-point range. The Saints limited the Stags to just 39 percent from the floor and 36 percent from long range. (AP)  WOMEN  MARYLAND 95, VIRGINIA 68 -- Crystal Langhorne had 17 points and 12 rebounds, Laura Harper had 21, and No. 3 Maryland bounced back from its first loss of the season by cruising past visiting Virginia.  Kristi Toliver scored 20 points and Marissa Coleman added 16 for the Terrapins (19-1, 3-1 Atlantic Coast Conference), the defending national champions, who were coming off an 82-61 defeat at Duke on Saturday that dropped them from the top spot in the Associated Press poll.  Lyndra Littles led Virginia (12-6, 2-2) with a career-high-tying 23points. The Cavaliers have lost fourin a row at Maryland. (AP)  COLLEGES
content.title: Seton Hall Drops Game After Losing A Starter

content.text: Forty-five of the world's top professional bull riders came to Manhattan this weekend for the Versus Invitational at Madison Square Garden, hoping to stay atop some of the nation's top bulls in the Professional Bull Riders tour's first visit to New York.  J. B. Mauney of Mooresville, N.C., last year's rookie of the year on the circuit, won the first event of his career by finishing fourth in the final round yesterday after a ride on a bull named The Boogerman. He and the second-place finisher, Steven Shelley, were the only two riders to score on all four of their bulls this weekend.  The three-time world champion Adriano Moraes of Brazil had won the first two rounds of competition Saturday, but he was thrown by his bull in the final round yesterday and finished third over all.  BULL RIDING
content.title: Rough Rides In the Big City

content.text: There were nine-tenths of a second left on the game clock when Danny Granger's 3-point attempt sailed past, and not through, the rim closest to the Knicks' bench Saturday night. The clock ticks that preceded that moment might have been the most anxious the Knicks had endured all week, which is saying a lot.  Last Wednesday, the Knicks lost to Washington on a dunk with 2.2 seconds left. On Friday, they lost to the Nets on a tip-in with 2.8 seconds left. So a 2-point lead late Saturday night against the Indiana Pacers was of no comfort when Granger pulled up from 29 feet.  ''I was holding my breath, saying all the Hail Marys and everything I possibly could,'' Coach Isiah Thomas said afterward. ''I know I couldn't take another heartbreaking loss like that at the end.''  The Knicks were spared a spirit-crushing conclusion this time. Granger, who had made three of six attempts from 3-point range, shot an air ball. Quentin Richardson gathered it, then heaved it into the air as the final buzzer sounded, and the Knicks escaped with a 108-106 victory at Conseco Fieldhouse.  The final score was about the only thing that felt good for the Knicks (18-24) at the end of another chaotic night. Eddy Curry was dominant, with 26 points, but fouled out with 2 minutes 31 seconds to play. Stephon Marbury had to pull himself from the game with 1:26 left because he could no longer run on an injured left knee.  The Knicks blew leads of 15 points in the third quarter and 10 points in the fourth, and they nearly lost the game with Marbury on the bench. They led by 6 points when Marbury left for good, but committed three consecutive turnovers against the Pacers' press. Indiana cut the deficit to a point twice in the final 11.2 seconds, both on Jermaine O'Neal layups. The Knicks held on, with Nate Robinson hitting three of four free throws in the final z10.1 seconds.  After that, the concern turned to Marbury's health.  ''I'm fine,'' he said.  Marbury said the injury was merely tendinitis and would not prevent him from playing Monday in Miami. Thomas seemed less certain.  ''We'll see where he's at,'' Thomas said. ''He's a pretty tough guy and he's been banged up all season long with that knee, and he's managed to get through.''  Marbury first injured the knee in a game here Dec. 15 but has not missed a game since then. He aggravated it in Friday's loss against the Nets, and twice more in the fourth quarter Saturday. Marbury hurt himself on a driving layup with 5:52 left, and grimaced as he jogged back up the court. But he did not take himself out until after he landed awkwardly when he was fouled with 1:42 left. In between, Jamaal Tinsley scored 6 points against Marbury, and the Pacers knocked an 8-point lead down to 2.  Marbury said the knee was not a factor in Tinsley's burst, but said he finally had to bench himself.  ''I would have been hurting the team if I had been out there,'' he said.  Marbury's absence was felt immediately. With the Pacers applying a press, Jamal Crawford threw away a pass. On the next possession, Malik Rose traveled as he crossed midcourt. Then Robinson committed a backcourt violation.  ''It was a hectic time,'' Rose said. ''We didn't do what we normally practice, and it almost cost us.''  An incensed Rose kicked a chair and bellowed for several minutes when he went back to the bench after his turnover. Rose said his anger was directed at himself and at the referees.  But the Knicks' worst stretch came in the third quarter, when the Pacers cut a 15-point deficit to 2. O'Neal, who had been quiet until then, got rolling and finished with 25 points and 10 rebounds. Granger had 19 points.  It was a disappointing finish for the Pacers (20-20) in the debut of their reconfigured roster after an eight-player trade with Golden State on Wednesday.  Mike Dunleavy, acquired in the deal, started at shooting guard and, after missing all four of his shots in the first half, scored 14 points in the second half. Troy Murphy, the other major player in the deal, came off the bench and had 10 points and 11 rebounds in 23 minutes.  Before the game, Pacers Coach Rick Carlisle defended the team's decision to trade the starters Al Harrington and Stephen Jackson. O'Neal criticized the trade after a game in Miami on Thursday night.  ''I felt like we had a crew of guys who could make it work,'' O'Neal said. ''With Al and those guys, I felt like we had the best five in the league.''  Carlisle said he was unaware of O'Neal's remarks, but he said that Donnie Walsh and Larry Bird, the team's top two officials, had talked to O'Neal about the trade.  ''This is part of the business,'' Carlisle said. ''If you want to get good players, you got to trade good players. My understanding is Larry and Don sat down with Jermaine and talked about the reasons for the trade. A lot of it was to enhance his ability as a franchise player. That was a real positive for him. On the other hand, it's tough when your best friends leave the team -- a guy like Al. We went through a lot to get him. None of us wanted to trade him.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Escape As Last Shot Brings Relief For a Change

content.text: On consecutive nights, the Nets have shown that resiliency and effort are slowly finding places in their team persona. But they are still learning how to catch a winning attitude.  After trailing by 16 points in the first half and by 8 in the third quarter against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Saturday night, the Nets battled back in the fourth, only to watch the game slip from their grasp in the closing minutes.  With a 96-91 loss to the Cavaliers, the Nets had their season-long winning streak of three games snapped, and they missed an opportunity to beat two of the Eastern Conference's best teams on consecutive nights.  On Friday night, the Nets overcame an 18-0 deficit to start the game against the Chicago Bulls and executed to perfection down the stretch to win by 5 points at Continental Arena.  After Saturday night's game here, Nets point guard Jason Kidd said: ''There were six minutes left and the momentum was in our favor, and we turned the ball over and took some bad shots. It was kind of the opposite of what we did last night.''  Still, Kidd echoed the sentiments of several of his teammates that the Nets (14-19), who have limped to one of the most disappointing starts in the National Basketball Association, finally have something to feel good about.  ''The effort was there,'' he said. ''And if we can build on what we've done the last four games in the sense of playing hard, we'll hopefully be in the win column more.''  Kidd, who had 11 points, 9 rebounds and 6 assists, said he was playing with a stiff back that he had hurt against the Bulls.  The Nets held LeBron James to a quiet 19 points and forced him into 5 turnovers. But the Cavaliers' frontcourt of Drew Gooden (21 points, 6 offensive rebounds) and Zydrunas Ilgauskas (16 points), along with guard Larry Hughes (21 points), picked up much of the slack.  The Nets' frontline was again depleted because their starting power forward, Jason Collins, missed his second consecutive game with a strained lower back. The reserve forward Josh Boone was also out of the game because of a migraine.  Yet the Nets got another impressive performance from center Mikki Moore, who has been shifted into the starting lineup because of the season-ending injury to Nenad Krstic. Moore scored 18 points and grabbed 10 rebounds.  Moore and a couple of his fellow role players opened the fourth quarter on a 14-4 run that turned a 6-point deficit into a 4-point lead.  The rookie point guard Marcus Williams led like a veteran during that stretch, getting a couple of open jump shots on pick-and-roll plays. He helped cap the run by finding his fellow rookie teammate Hassan Adams with a lob pass for an emphatic dunk.  ''Those guys did a very good job to get us in that position,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''In the last seven minutes, unfortunately, it was a combination of lack of ability to get defensive stops and lack of ability to score down the stretch, obviously, that determined the outcome of the game.''  With the score tied at 83-83, Ilagauskas got an open dunk courtesy of a pass from James. Kidd lost the ball on his team's next possession, eventually leading to a reverse dunk by James. Two possessions later, Gooden scored on a driving two-handed dunk. Moments later, Hughes all but sealed the game for the Cavaliers with a layup.  ''The last six minutes, we pride ourselves in trying to out-execute teams, and we did it for maybe five minutes,'' said Vince Carter, who scored 18 points.  One encouraging sign for the Nets was the play of small forward Richard Jefferson, who finished with 17 points. Jefferson has struggled this season because of injuries to both ankles, and many people within the Nets' organization have cited his lack of explosiveness as a direct reason for the team's problems.  During the Nets' three-game winning streak, Jefferson shot 56.4 percent from the field and averaged 21 points, both well above his season averages.  Power forward Cliff Robinson, who was playing in only his second game Saturday night after missing a month and a half because of an injured left knee, pointed to another possibility for the Nets' early struggles: a lack of accountability.  Robinson, 40, is the longest-tenured player in the N.B.A., and one of the few Nets willing to correct his teammates when they do something wrong.  ''You're not out there to step on anyone's toes or hurt anyone's feelings,'' he said before the game.
