''But at the same time, if you can't take constructive criticism, you're in the wrong business.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: The Nets Lose a Step Down the Stretch

content.text: Jason Kidd, 33, had played nearly 43 minutes against the Chicago Bulls and still was relentlessly pursuing Kirk Hinrich, a point guard who is seven years younger.  On the final play of Thursday night's game at the United Center, with the Nets holding a 3-point lead, Kidd disrupted Hinrich's dribble, forcing him to attempt an off-balance 3-pointer that was blocked by Nets forward Bostjan Nachbar. Time expired, and the Nets beat the Bulls, 86-83.  It was the second consecutive victory for the Nets (16-19), and it blemished Chicago's 13-0 home record against Eastern Conference opponents.  Kidd (23 points, 14 rebounds, 11 assists) recorded his 82nd triple-double. If he was distracted by his split from his wife, Joumana, which became public this week, he certainly did not show it. Kidd's performance was so dazzling that his coach, Lawrence Frank, nearly credited him alone for the victory.  ''It's a team victory,'' Frank said, ''but to make the understatement of the short year, without him, we don't have a chance in this game.''  Kidd's stellar play began early in the second half after the Bulls outscored the Nets, 6-2, in just over a minute and a half to extend their halftime lead to 18 points. Frank called a timeout, and Kidd apparently found a cape on the bench. He quickly made a pair of shots to spark a 22-6 run that drew the Nets to within 2 points.  His energy sparked the Nets' defense, which at one point held the Bulls scoreless for nearly five minutes on 0-for-7 shooting from the field.  Kidd and the Nets made their decisive statement midway through the fourth quarter when they showed the resolve of an elite team, using a 14-0 spurt to take control of the game.  The Nets prevented the Bulls from scoring on eight consecutive possessions, and Chicago shot 0 for 9 from the field. When Kidd hit a 3-pointer from the corner with 5 minutes 41 seconds to play, the Nets went ahead, 75-74, their first lead since they went ahead by 2-0 a minute into the game.  Kidd's teammates did not hear him say a word during their game-changing runs. But his play spoke volumes.  ''He's a special guy,'' Eddie House said. ''He's not really into the talking too much. He leads by example.''  Kidd was also reserved as he spoke about his performance after the game.  ''My job was just to try to inject some energy,'' he said. ''Hopefully, I did that.''  The Nets finally seem to be finding the swagger of a year ago, when they used winning streaks of 10 and 14 games to cruise to the Atlantic Division title. And with their runs in the third and fourth quarters, they are showing they know how to shift gears when it counts.  ''That's the Nets that I'm used to seeing,'' power forward Cliff Robinson said. ''Being able to clamp down and get stops when they're needed.''  The Nets held the Bulls' sixth man, Ben Gordon, to just 3 points in the second half after he scored 20 in the first. Frank gave Kidd much of the credit, saying he prevented Gordon from even touching the ball on many possessions.  The Nets are also showing determination.  On one possession the, Nets got offensive rebounds after 3-point misses by Kidd and Nachbar. Center Mikki Moore finally ended the sequence by throwing down a dunk and a scream.  Rod Thorn, the Nets' president, now has reason to believe his team can contend in the Eastern Conference. ''Right now, you can't say that anyone's dominant in the Eastern Conference,'' he said Thursday.  Even before the game, Thorn said he felt his team was starting to prove it could compete consistently.  ''Sometime during the season, if you're a quality team, you get into a rhythm, a groove, and you play well,'' Thorn said. ''I see a lot of good signs. Our spirit seems to be good; confidence level's up. Hopefully, we can continue to play well.''  REBOUNDS  The Nets rookie point guard Marcus Williams did not make the trip to Chicago because of strep throat.  Power forward Chris Webber, who agreed to a buyout with the Philadelphia 76ers, did not mention the Nets as one of the teams he is interested in, which led Rod Thorn to say, ''I don't think we're on his radar.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: What Distractions? Kidd Leads Way for the Nets

content.text: In the excitement of a shootout against the Devils on Tuesday night, a game the Rangers felt they desperately needed to win, Marcel Hossa took the ice as the Rangers' eighth shooter.  He followed a trail of sharpshooting teammates, including Jaromir Jagr, Brendan Shanahan and Martin Straka. But if he was nervous in such a crucial spot, he betrayed none of it.  ''He just looked like the smoothest, coolest guy out there,'' Shanahan said.  As Hossa skated in on Devils goalie Martin Brodeur, he pulled Brodeur wide and calmly fired a shot into the upper left corner, then turned to smile at his teammates, who were celebrating wildly.  One more save by Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist, on Travis Zajac, and the Rangers were celebrating a 3-2 victory over a team that seems to bring out the best in them.  The victory pulled the Rangers (20-17-4) a point closer to the Devils (22-13-4), who lead the Atlantic Division. The Rangers, 4 points behind the Devils in second place, have won three of the teams' four meetings this season.  But the most important part of this one was mental.  Just four days earlier, the Rangers were mired in a seven-game losing streak. They ended it with a home victory Saturday against Washington, but beating a struggling team at home does not offer the same boost in confidence that beating a first-place team on the road does.  And they vanquished the Devils in spectacular fashion.  Lundqvist had stopped all 22 shots he had faced in the Rangers' four shootouts this season, a record that came to a screeching halt when Zach Parise scored on the Devils' first shot. In all, Lundqvist gave up three goals in the shootout. But Brodeur allowed goals to Michael Nylander Shanahan, Matt Cullen and Hossa.  It was the second time this season that Hossa won a shootout for the Rangers; he put a shot through the pads of Flyers goalie Antero Niittymaki in the 13th round on Oct. 7 in Philadelphia.  Hossa has scored only once in regulation this season. His shot against the Flyers, however, helped him climb a few notches up the shootout chart. Hossa said it had also increased his confidence in trying a far more difficult shot against Brodeur.  ''I was thinking I would go five-hole again, but maybe my brother scored too many goals on him five-hole so he would think I was going to do the same,'' Hossa said, laughing, referring to his brother Marian, a star forward for Atlanta who has scored 23 more goals than he has this season. ''This time I did a different thing and it went through.''  The Devils said they were happy to collect a point for taking the game to overtime. Jamie Langenbrunner's power-play goal with 4 minutes 12 seconds left in regulation allowed them to tie the score at 2-2.  ''It was a hard-earned point,'' Devils Coach Claude Julien said. ''We'll take it and move on.''  Langenbrunner had a chance to win the game in the shootout as well, as the Devils' seventh shooter, pulling Lundqvist wide and nearly stuffing in a backhand. But Lundqvist stretched his glove to the right post and nudged the puck aside.  That turn of events allowed Hossa to score the winner.  The Rangers played a solid game to reach the shootout. After falling behind, 1-0, in the first on a goal by John Madden, they came back on goals by Nylander and Petr Prucha before Langenbrunner tied it late.  The remarkable part of Prucha's goal was how the puck got to him. Jagr deflected a pass from defenseman Karel Rachunek with his right skate and sent it to a waiting Prucha, unguarded at the left post.  ''I tried to kick it in the net,'' Jagr said. ''I missed that. I wanted to go top shelf. I'll be working on it tomorrow.''  Shootouts, it seems, have become a specialty for the Rangers, who are now 5-1 in them. And they can turn to their secret weapon when they need to win one.  ''It was a terrific move,'' Renney said of Hossa's shot. ''This is one of the best goalies to ever play the game. Hoss should feel good about himself right about now.''  SLAP SHOTS  Rangers forward Jed Ortmeyer played his first game since doctors found he had a pulmonary embolism in August. He played only nine shifts, for 5 minutes 35 seconds of ice time. Forward Jarkko Immonen was a healthy scratch. ... Devils defenseman Colin White missed his fourth straight game with a groin injury.  HOCKEY
content.title: Hossa Delivers for Rangers in Shootout With Devils

content.text: Jason Kidd hit a shot Friday night that had his teammate Hassan Adams running in place and screaming on the sideline like a child in a schoolyard. The shot left many in Continental Arena with ear-to-ear grins, wide-eyed looks and hanging jaws.  Yet that may not have been the most spectacular thing they witnessed.  That distinction might belong to the Nets' shaking off an 18-0 deficit and defeating the Chicago Bulls, 91-86, in their first game of the new year.  The Nets (14-18) showed the type of resiliency they could only have dreamed of through their disappointing first 31 games of the season.  ''To me, the most impressive thing is, compared to some prior games that we've had, we kept our composure, we kept our poise,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''We didn't break.''  Chicago got out to that 18-0 lead by hitting 7 of its first 10 shots and forcing the Nets into four turnovers. The Nets missed their first nine shots and did not score until Richard Jefferson hit a free throw 6 minutes 34 seconds into the game.  That start was a distant memory by the beginning of the fourth quarter, when the Bulls led by only 2 points. The Nets executed in those final 12 minutes, yet another quality they have lacked for much of the season. Nine times this season, the Nets have squandered leads in the final six minutes.  But Friday night, their execution was punctuated by several timely shots late in the game.  Vince Carter, who led the Nets with 21 points, hit a long jumper over Kirk Hinrich with 1:05 to play that gave the Nets an 85-84 lead they did not relinquish.  On the Bulls' next possession, Kidd (17 points, 10 rebounds, 7 assists, 5 steals) slapped the ball from Ben Gordon's hands. He raced the other way for an uncontested layup that gave the Nets an 87-84 lead with 53 seconds left.  That play provided a prelude to his circus shot.  Kidd drove past Adrian Griffin along the baseline and into the middle of the lane. With Wallace in his way, Kidd turned his back to the basket and flicked the ball over his head with his left hand. The shot banked in to give the Nets an 89-84 advantage with 15 seconds to play.  ''I was a little stuck,'' Kidd said, ''and I just threw it up, hoping that it would just hit the rim and kind of kill time.''  Small forward Richard Jefferson, who scored 18 points, called it ''one of the craziest on-purpose shots I have ever seen at the end of the game.''  Adams said: ''It was crazy that he did that. It felt like it was in rhythm, like he'd been doing that, like a go-to move.''  In the fourth quarter, forward Bostjan Nachbar made two 3-pointers for the Nets. He was making his first start of the season, and he tied a season high with 16 points.  The Nets have won three games in a row for the first time this season and may finally be able to speak with some confidence, having beaten the Bulls (19-14), one of the Eastern Conference's best teams.  The Nets won the game without Jason Collins, their starting power forward, who missed the game with a strained lower back.  The Nets will have little time to celebrate. They travel to Cleveland on Saturday for a game against the Cavaliers and LeBron James.  At this time a year ago, the Nets were in the midst of a 10-game winning streak. Later in the season, the Nets had a 14-game winning streak that created a bravado they relied on for the rest of their schedule.  On Thursday, Carter reflected on those winning streaks by saying, ''We just felt unbeatable.''  He added: ''It's just not the case right now. We feel like we have to win by any means necessary. Last year, we kind of felt, especially during those two win streaks, even when we were losing, we still felt like we could walk on the floor and beat anybody.''  Slowly but surely, the Nets are trying to regain that swagger, one trick shot at a time.  REBOUNDS  Nets center Nenad Krstic, who sustained a season-ending tear of his anterior cruciate ligament two weeks ago, spoke with reporters for the first time since then before Friday night's game against the Bulls. Krstic, wearing jeans and a sweater and lounging on a leather sofa, said that he was over the initial shock and that he felt good mentally and physically. Krstic is to have surgery Wednesday, and he said that doctors told him he could be playing basketball again by June or July.  The swingman Bernard Robinson, who was acquired from the Charlotte Bobcats for point guard Jeff McInnis on Wednesday, joined the Nets on Friday. He was inactive for the game against the Bulls.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Keep Composure and Pull Off Comeback

content.text: For now, Seton Hall looks like the best Big East basketball team from the state of New Jersey. For the Pirates, that may be as good as it gets the rest of this season.  In front of a small crowd (7,214) at Continental Arena that included an impartial Gov. Jon S. Corzine, Seton Hall defeated interstate rival Rutgers, 77-72, Wednesday night.  The game kicked off the Big East portion of the schedule for Seton Hall and Rutgers, which figures to mean problems for both. Neither team fared particularly well in the nonconference portion of their schedules and must now play much tougher opponents.  Both have first-year coaches and are in a rebuilding mode. Bobby Gonzalez has come over from Manhattan to try to get Seton Hall (9-4, 1-0) back on track. Fred Hill is the new coach at Rutgers (7-7, 0-1).  So far, it is Gonzalez's team that seems to be on the faster track.  ''We don't know how long we are going to stay undefeated in the league, but the bottom line is that we're 9-4 and we won our first Big East game, and it's a rivalry game,'' Gonzalez said. ''Rivalry games are important. We've got to find ways to win games and scratch and claw. That's what we did. That's what we're going to have to do every game. No games this year are going to be easy for us.''  The Pirates have a talented freshman, Eugene Harvey, they can build around. A point guard, he had 21 points for Seton Hall on Wednesday. Brian Laing also had 21.  ''Eugene Harvey makes everyone else on the floor better,'' Hill said. ''Everybody gets worried about Eugene's penetration and that opens up the floor for Laing and Jamar Nutter. He's their catalyst and he makes them go. The better Eugene plays and as he continues to develop and grow, they will develop and grow as a team.''  It appeared early on that Seton Hall was going to run away with the game. The Pirates had a 34-16 lead with 5 minutes 17 seconds to go in the first half.  But the Scarlet Knights went on a 17-0 run to cut the Pirates' lead to 34-33. Rutgers had its first lead, 54-53, on a hook shot by J. R. Inman with 10:11 to go. Seton Hall then started to take control. When Harvey scored on a driving layup with 4:44 to play, the Pirates had a 68-61 lead.  Rutgers was not done. When Hamaday N'Diaye dunked with 1:07 left to go, the Seton Hall lead was down to 68-66. Making 9 of 10 free-throw attempts inside the final minute, Seton Hall was able to close out the game.  Rutgers was led by Inman, who had 18 points and 12 rebounds.  ST. JOHN'S 64, DEPAUL 53 -- Aaron Spears, playing for the first time since serving a four-game suspension, scored all 6 of his points in the final nine and a half minutes and St. John's won a Big East opener at Madison Square Garden.  Daryll Hill, who has battled a knee injury all season, had 9 points for the Red Storm (10-4), including a 3-pointer from deep in the corner as the shot clock ran out for a 59-52 lead with 45 seconds to play.  Wilson Chandler had 15 points for the Blue Demons (9-6).  Hill, who came in averaging 6.5 points a game, and Spears, who was averaging 2.8, combined to score 12 straight points for the Red Storm in the second half.(AP)  NOTRE DAME 78, LOUISVILLE 62 -- Tory Jackson, a freshman point guard, tied a career high with 14 points to help 17th-ranked Notre Dame beat visiting Louisville in a Big East opener. Jackson was put in the starting lineup after Kyle McAlarney was arrested on a marijuana possession charge last week and suspended indefinitely.  Notre Dame (13-1) has won 12 consecutive games for the first time in nearly 33 years. Terrence Williams led Louisville (10-5) with 18 points, but the Cardinals continued to struggle offensively. (AP)  NORTH CAROLINA 102, PENNSYLVANIA 64 -- Tyler Hansbrough and Reyshawn Terry scored 19 points apiece, and No. 2 North Carolina routed visiting Pennsylvania for its 10th straight victory. Wayne Ellington added 17 points for North Carolina (13-1), which used a 27-4 run late in the first half to take command against the Quakers (6-6). (AP)  WEST VIRGINIA 67, VILLANOVA 56 -- Frank Young scored a career-high 25 points, including eight 3-pointers, for No. 25 West Virginia (12-1, 2-0) in a Big East game. Curtis Sumpter, conference's second-leading scorer, led visiting Villanova (10-3, 0-1) with 21 points. (AP)  GEORGE WASHINGTON 70, FORDHAM 59 -- Maureece Rice had 17 points and 6 rebounds to lead George Washington (9-3) past visiting Fordham in the Atlantic 10 opener for both teams. Marcus Stout had 15 points for Fordham (7-6) to give him 1,001 in his career. (AP)  IN OTHER GAMES -- Dan Nwaelele led a balanced offense with 22 points, and No. 20 Air Force (14-1, 1-0 Mountain West Conference) beat Colorado State, 81-75, for its 10th straight victory.  Cliff Hammonds's layup with three seconds left lifted No. 23 Clemson (15-0) past Florida State, 68-66, in the Atlantic Coast Conference opener for both teams. (AP)  WOMEN  MARYLAND 80, NORTH CAROLINA STATE 61 -- Top-ranked Maryland (16-0) opened Atlantic Coast Conference play in the same fashion it handled the nonleague portion of its schedule: with a blowout victory. Laura Harper scored 17 points and Coach Brenda Frese earned her 100th win at Maryland.  Shay Doron scored 10 points to move into second place on the Terps' career scoring list. Doron, a senior guard, has 1,681 points. (AP)  DUKE 72, MIAMI 42 -- Carrem Gay had 12 points and 10 rebounds to lead third-ranked Duke (15-0) past Miami in the A.C.C. (AP)  TENNESSEE 72, ALABAMA 36 -- In a Southeastern Conference opener, Candace Parker scored 15 points and No. 4 Tennessee (13-1) beat visiting Alabama (10-6) for the 31st consecutive time. (AP)  COLLEGE BASKETBALL: ROUNDUP
content.title: Seton Hall Starts Big East Play On Right Track, Beating Rutgers

content.text: A cruel sort of familiarity came over the Knicks last night, as they stared at the wrong end of a lopsided score and watched another star player limp away. A few more games like this could destroy their morale, if not their season.  The injured star was center Eddy Curry, who has become the Knicks' most irreplaceable player. He strained his left calf muscle early in the fourth quarter, just as the Phoenix Suns surged to a 17-point lead at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks avoided the rout, losing, 112-107, but they could not avoid another night of furrowed brows and deep sighs.  Stephon Marbury was already out, resting a sore knee that knocked him out of Monday night's blowout loss in Miami. Marbury said he planned to be back tomorrow when the Heat go to the Garden, but now it is Curry whose status is up in the air.  The Knicks offered no official prognosis, and Coach Isiah Thomas said, ''I don't know what his situation will be.''  The most optimistic voice belonged to Curry, who predicted he would be fine for tomorrow's showdown with Shaquille O'Neal. But Curry said he could not be sure until he sees how the calf responds overnight. A similar injury cost Curry five games last season, but he said this one was not as severe.  ''Definitely not as bad,'' Curry said. ''I'm not expecting to miss any time, but you don't really know with these type of things.''  According to Curry, the team doctors believe the injury is ''fairly significant, but they think there's a good chance I'll play Friday.''  The Suns (34-8) won their 15th straight game, tying a franchise record they set earlier this season. Amare Stoudemire led the way, scoring 26 of his 30 points in the second half. Steve Nash, who is sprinting toward a possible third straight Most Valuable Player award, had 22 points and 14 assists.  The Knicks (18-26) fell eight games below .500, matching their low point of the season. After briefly making a run at the Atlantic Division lead, the Knicks have lost five of seven games and are three and a half games behind Toronto.  Still, the Knicks nearly survived Marbury's absence last night. They cannot afford to lose Curry, their leading scorer and the focal point of their offensive system. No one on the roster can do what he does.  ''I don't even want to think about it,'' Jamal Crawford said of losing Curry.  Curry was barreling toward a career game, scoring 21 points in the first half and overpowering Stoudemire.  ''He's a load,'' Suns Coach Mike D'Antoni said.  Curry said the calf began to feel tight when he started the third quarter. It was evident in his play. Curry picked up two quick fouls guarding Stoudemire and stopped attacking on offense. The training staff had Curry put a sleeve over the calf to keep it loose.  ''I kind of knew when it started to tighten up that if I push off on it too fast that it'd be a problem,'' Curry said. ''So I kind of had to gauge myself out there and pick my spots.''  But 1 minute 20 seconds into the fourth quarter, Curry caught a pass on the right block and spun aggressively toward the basket for a layup. He came down with a wince and could not run back up the court. He limped to the sideline and later retreated to the locker room.  ''It's just in my nature to get the ball and try to score,'' Curry said. ''It just kind of gave out on me.''  The Knicks trailed by 87-70 when Curry left. Crawford, as he so often has, seized the moment. He scored 23 points in the fourth quarter, and along with David Lee, nearly rallied the Knicks to the comeback.  Crawford hit two free throws with 41.5 seconds left to cut the deficit to 6 points, then hit two more to make it a 5-point game with 25.6 seconds left. But the Knicks ran out of time, and Nash made three of four free throws to close out the victory.  Crawford, starting in place of Marbury, had 29 points and 11 assists and played all 48 minutes. Curry finished with 25 points in 31 minutes. Lee had 17 points and 14 rebounds off the bench. Nate Robinson, who played most of the second half next to Crawford, also had 17 points but shot 5 of 19 from the field.  Quentin Richardson, a former Sun and the Knicks' best shooter, missed all five of his shots and went scoreless in 24 minutes.  Phoenix pulled away by hitting seven 3-pointers in the second half (after making just two in the first half) and by getting to the foul line. They made 22 of 31 free throws in the second half. Without Curry, the Knicks' inside game dried up.  Marbury watched the game in a suit and tie, but before tip-off he said he was ''definitely playing Friday'' when the Heat -- with O'Neal and Dwyane Wade back in the lineup -- visits the Garden. Miami routed the Knicks by 18 points Monday.  The Knicks have weathered the absence of several players already, and Thomas said they could survive Curry's as well.  ''It'd be tough, but we'll manage,'' he said. ''We'll find a way to make it work.''  REBOUNDS  Stephon Marbury's troublesome left knee felt good enough to run yesterday but not ready for jumping and cutting. He said that another 48 hours of rest would be enough and that he had no doubt about playing tomorrow night. Marbury said the knee will not be pain free when he returns, but it will be much better than it was when he was forced to sit out the second half of Monday's loss at Miami. ''These two days are going to be huge for me,'' Marbury said. ''It's just like more stiff than hurting. The pain part is gone, as far as the way how it felt when I initially did it.'' Marbury said he had already adjusted his game to compensate for the knee, which he originally injured Dec. 15. ''I'm playing smarter,'' he said. ''I wasn't going to the basket like how I did four or five years ago.''  For the second straight game, Jared Jeffries opened the second half on the bench. He was replaced by Nate Robinson and did not return until the final 25.6 seconds of the fourth quarter. Jeffries has been ineffective lately and was booed by fans several times last night. ''We depend on him to bring energy,'' Isiah Thomas said before the game. ''It won't necessarily show up on the stat sheet, but he's got to find a way to affect the game with his energy.''  BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Avoid Rout, but Not Another Loss

content.text: The Nets thought they were finished with games like this.  It was not just the fourth-quarter collapse, which enabled the Minnesota Timberwolves to pull away and win, 109-98. In both the first and third quarters, the Nets failed to add to modest leads that could have helped them withstand Kevin Garnett's big second half and the Timberwolves' furious 37-point fourth quarter.  Garnett finished with 32 points and 14 rebounds, with 12 points each coming in third and fourth quarters. Garnett's energy sparked Minnesota's remarkable fourth-quarter shooting from the field (11 for 16) and the free-throw line (15 for 15). And it left the Nets losers for only the second time in seven games.  ''Just because you have a lot of energy doesn't necessarily mean you're not tired,'' said Garnett, who grabbed his 10,000th career rebound in a game that came one night after a 116-110 victory against Memphis. ''Lord knows I was. But it's part of the league, and I'm pretty used to it.''  Improved defense had characterized this recent good stretch for the Nets, which made the manner of the loss tougher to take. The Nets had not allowed this many points in a game since Dec. 23, a 115-104 loss at Milwaukee.  It did not help that the Nets, after shooting 53.1 percent from the field through three quarters, missed 12 of 18 attempts in the fourth quarter and committed six turnovers. Or that, after leading, 67-57, with 5 minutes 46 seconds left in the third quarter, the Nets never extended the lead and were outscored by 52-31 the rest of the way.  The aggressive Timberwolves were 56.9 percent from the field and 32 of 35 from the free-throw line. Garnett was perfect on 11 attempts. The Nets took only 14 free throws and made 11. Ricky Davis added 17 points and Randy Foye had 16 for the Timberwolves, who had five players in double figures.  ''Defensively, we just had so many breakdowns,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''Then what happens is, it gets magnified, and then we made some poor decisions on the offensive end. You don't give yourself any margin for error if you can't put together stops.''  Forward Richard Jefferson said: ''In the third quarter we should have gone from 10 to 17 points, and we didn't. In the fourth quarter, we just died.''  The Nets wasted an earlier chance to pull away when Vince Carter (24 points) sat out much of the first half because of foul trouble. The Nets led by 8 in the first quarter, but were only ahead by 48-46 at halftime.  Not even Jason Kidd, after his triple-double in Thursday's comeback victory at Chicago, could rescue the Nets. Kidd finished with 24 points, 13 assists, 6 rebounds and 6 steals, but he also committed 5 turnovers.  ''It was surprising for us,'' Kidd said of the team's fourth-quarter play. ''The last six or seven games, in the fourth quarter, we buckled down. Tonight, you've got to give Minnesota credit. It was the other way around.''  The Nets led, 81-77, early in the fourth quarter when the Timberwolves ran off 10 straight points to take their first lead. Garnett scored 6 of the points -- a jumper that hit the rim, bounced high and through; a fast-break dunk after a Carter throwback pass to no one; and another dunk out of a halfcourt set.  A Carter free throw with 6:49 left stopped the drought, but the Nets could make no more headway. Garnett pump-faked Mikki Moore airborne, drove the lane, took a hammering inside and made two free throws with 4:50 left to make the score 93-85 in favor of the Timberwolves. After that, the Nets never came closer than 7 points.  ''With them getting easy buckets in the paint and also getting to the free-throw line,'' Frank said, ''it puts huge pressure that you have to be almost flawless on the offensive end. Obviously, in the fourth quarter, we weren't that.''  REBOUNDS  The N.B.A. suspended Chicago forward ANDRES NOCIONI one game for elbowing MIKKI MOORE in the head Thursday. The league also rescinded the technical foul called against Moore after the play, saving him the $1,000 fine.  Timberwolves forward EDDIE GRIFFIN, whom the Nets drafted No. 7 over all in 2001, served the second game of his five-game suspension for violating the league's anti-drug policy. Griffin fell out of Coach Dwane Casey's rotation early in the season and had not played for 13 games before the suspension. The Nets acquired RICHARD JEFFERSON and JASON COLLINS from Houston for Griffin in a draft-day trade.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Defense Falters and Nets Fade in Fourth Quarter

content.text: High point totals are a common occurrence for Vince Carter, but they are not the true mark of his dominance. That is typically measured by how inclined he is to shun jump shots for a taste of the rim.  Carter was that unstoppable high flier Saturday night, scoring 40 points, 20 in the fourth quarter, to lead the Nets to a much needed 112-102 victory against the Denver Nuggets.  The Nets (21-23) won their first road game against a Western Conference team this season and snapped a gut-wrenching streak of three consecutive 1-point losses to start this five-game Western trip.  ''The good part is we won,'' said Nets forward Bostjan Nachbar, who scored a career-high 22 points. ''The sad part is we should be 4-0.''  Carter outshone the other two superstar scorers on the court, Carmelo Anthony and Allen Iverson, who combined for only 41 points Saturday night after scoring 70 a night earlier against the Utah Jazz.  The Nets pointed to their commitment to team defense as the reason they were able to slow Anthony and Iverson.  What was also special about this performance for the Nets was the contributions from all around. In addition to Nachbar's scoring, Antoine Wright returned to the rotation for 11 points and played excellent defense against Anthony. Jason Kidd scored 18 points and had 12 rebounds. And the rookie backup point guard Marcus Williams scored 11 points.  ''When you play a team like Denver, you're going to need everyone to contribute, and our guys did a good job of that,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said.  The contributions started with a lineup of reserves, led by Nachbar and Williams, pulling the Nets back into the game in the second quarter after falling behind by double digits after the first. It continued with Kidd, the team captain, showing his excellence in the third quarter with 12 points on four 3-pointers and 7 rebounds. And, when the game counted the most in the fourth quarter, the ball went to the Nets' superstar, Carter.  Carter got 10 of his 12 free throws in the fourth quarter, a sign of his willingness to drive to the basket.  Carter, who shot 14 of 23 from the floor and had 7 rebounds and 6 assists, has been criticized at times for settling for jump shots and not having the mental fortitude to be consistently dominant.  ''What, I think, Vince has done, he's touched the specialness, but he doesn't quite comprehend the fundamental nature that he has to play at to be there consistently,'' Nuggets Coach George Karl said before Saturday night's game.  After the game, Nachbar said of Carter: ''When he plays like that, we're a different kind of team. He's basically unstoppable when he puts his mind to it.''  Carter may have found some added motivation during the first three games of this trip. He had costly mistakes in each one. Against the Sacramento Kings on Monday night, he missed a pair of foul shots late in the game. He fouled the Golden State Warriors' Baron Davis on a 3-point attempt and gave up a costly charging foul Wednesday night. And he left the Clippers' Cuttino Mobley open for the winning 3-pointer Thursday night.  Carter took the blame after those games and got down on himself, something he does not typically do.  ''It's tough to lose by 1 point and then it's tough to be the one to let it happen,'' Carter said after Saturday night's game. ''I took that personal. I just can't let that happen. I wanted to erase that.''  The victory against the Nuggets could help the entire Nets team forget the mental burden of their three defeats.  The Nets' team effort might have best been represented in their ability to limit Anthony (23 points) and Iverson (18 points). They did it by crowding the paint, smothering and limiting them to outside shots or off-balanced looks when they got close to the rim.  Wright was the biggest beneficiary of the Iverson-Anthony duo. Frank put Wright, who had not played in 12 of the Nets' previous 19 games, in the starting lineup Saturday night for his defense. Wright said his ability to make Anthony struggle was more pleasing than a thunderous one-handed dunk he had early in the third quarter.  ''I knew there could be a night like this where Coach is going to call me to play,'' Wright said. ''So I just try to stay in shape. I think that helped me tonight.''  Nachbar was once in Wright's position -- a reserve who had fallen out of the rotation. But he has been one of the team's most significant contributors of late, benefiting from the attention Carter draws in the form of open shots.  Nachbar has averaged 17.7 points in the past three games and is a symbol of what the Nets could be when everyone shows up.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Carter Gets 40 and Support, Letting Nets Exhale

content.text: With three games left before the season's mathematical midpoint, the Knicks' image remains a curious mosaic of contradictions.  After consecutive routs of three of the N.B.A.'s worst teams, Coach Isiah Thomas declared that the Knicks should now be expected to beat the N.B.A.'s worst teams. Then the Charlotte Bobcats came to New York and routed them by 16 points.  Weakened by suspensions and injuries in late December, the Knicks beat three top-tier opponents -- Utah, Chicago and Detroit. Faced with a string of sub-.500 opponents -- Sacramento, the Clippers, Portland, Seattle, Philadelphia and Charlotte -- the Knicks proceeded to go 3-3.  The Knicks have been lauded this season for their resilience. But their loss Friday to the Bobcats left them 2-20 in games they trailed at halftime.  For all the recent flashes of promise, the Knicks are 16-22 -- shaky enough to hold the 11th-best record in the Eastern Conference, but solid enough to be in contention for the Atlantic Division title and a playoff berth.  To put it more simply, the Knicks are a typical rebuilding project, albeit one with a massive payroll and a lot of former lottery picks in the rotation. They are young and inconsistent, teasing their fans with surprising victories and infuriating them with unforgivable defeats.  The Knicks are 11-11 since a 5-11 start, and there are certainly more wild fluctuations to come. The roster finally returned to full strength last week (minus guard Steve Francis, who has always been superfluous), so Thomas is again retooling the rotation and fiddling with the chemistry.  Quentin Richardson appears to be healthy after missing 11 games because of a back injury. He averaged 18 points, 8 rebounds, 3 assists and 2.5 steals in his first two games back, making a strong case to return to the starting lineup. That would force Thomas to send Jamal Crawford, Jared Jeffries or Channing Frye to the bench. The current lineup is 4-5, so Thomas would not be breaking up any magic combinations.  Nate Robinson, the other key player to return last week -- after a 10-game suspension for his role in the Dec. 16 brawl with Denver -- is not yet himself. Robinson vowed to suppress his wilder side, but he also seems to have lost his confident stride. He went scoreless in two games last week, going 0 for 4 from the field in 18 minutes. Yet he still managed to draw a technical foul Friday night. In the 5 minutes 48 seconds he played, Robinson had extensive conversations with two of the three referees.  Thomas had more options last week, but he relied primarily on eight players -- Eddy Curry, Stephon Marbury, David Lee, Jeffries, Frye, Crawford, Richardson and Robinson. Thomas still seems to be searching for the best way to deploy Jeffries and Lee, in particular.  Jeffries was signed last summer to bolster the Knicks' defense, but his lack of scoring punch can be a drag on the offense. Thomas played him just 16 minutes Friday (3 in the second half), preferring to use Richardson (38 minutes) and Lee (27 minutes), despite the Knicks' inability to contain the Bobcats' shooters.  The newly crowded frontcourt rotation has seemed to affect Lee the most. A linchpin of the Knicks' success in the weeks after the brawl, Lee lost some steam last week, averaging only 9 points and 5.5 rebounds in two games. He had been averaging a double-double.  And the Knicks continue to wait for Frye to become a reliable scoring threat. He had 10 points in the first quarter against Charlotte, but only 2 the rest of the night. Thomas continues to start Frye, but often leaves him on the bench in the fourth quarter.  By Feb. 1, the Knicks could just as easily be division leaders or bottom dwellers. Over the next 10 games, they play just four teams with winning records (Washington, Indiana, Phoenix and the Lakers). But they also have two games with the Miami Heat, whose losing record could be offset by the imminent return of Shaquille O'Neal.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: No Method to Knicks' Maddening First Half

content.text: When you are as hot, as brilliant and as close to perfect as Jamal Crawford was last night, the record shattering does not end at the final buzzer. An hour after Crawford lit up the Madison Square Garden scoreboard and the Miami Heat, he picked up his cell phone.  ''Twenty-four messages,'' Crawford said in disbelief. ''Never had that many before. It's usually six.''  It was the only time all night that Crawford seemed in awe of anything. The dumbfounded expressions mostly belonged to the Heat, and Crawford was the one who put them there.  Delivering the best individual Knick performance in nearly four years, Crawford scored 52 points to lead a 116-96 rout and cause a sudden bottleneck in the wireless voice-mail network.  The scoring total beat Crawford's career high by 2 points and represented the fifth-highest total in franchise history. It was perfectly timed, as well; the Knicks were missing their leading scorer, Eddy Curry, and were desperate for a victory after a rough week.  ''That was heavenly intervention,'' said Jerome James, who took Curry's place in the starting lineup and checked Shaquille O'Neal.  Only four nights earlier, the Heat (19-24) routed the Knicks (19-26) by 18 points in a game that ranked among their worst this season. They had lost five of their past seven games, and another defeat would have dropped them nine games below .500, which would have been a new low.  Instead, the Garden was filled with roars of delight, chants of Crawford's name and one very large group hug by the Knicks' bench. They routed the defending champion Heat for the second time this season -- and this time with both Dwyane Wade and O'Neal (albeit briefly) in the lineup.  ''I wasn't even thinking about it being my night. I just wanted to take what was there,'' Crawford said.  Crawford made 20 of 30 field goals, went 8 for 10 from 3-point range and converted all four of his free throws. During a 23-minute stretch -- from late in the first quarter to late in the third -- Crawford hit 16 consecutive shots, including all eight of the 3-pointers, for 42 points.  According to the Elias Sports Bureau, no other player has converted that many in a row in a game in the past 10 years (the only years they could track). O'Neal was the last to hit 16 straight, over two games in February 2006. Crawford fell three shots short of Johnny Newman's franchise record for consecutive makes over two games in 1988.  The streak ended for Crawford when he missed a 19-footer with 2 minutes 17 seconds left in the third quarter. He struck again, making an 11-footer 21 seconds later.  ''I didn't look at anybody. I just stayed in my own zone,'' said Crawford, whose previous high of 50 points came on April 11, 2004, while playing for the Chicago Bulls in a game against Toronto.  Coach Isiah Thomas said he was unaware of Crawford's career mark, but he happened to leave him in just long enough to beat it. Thomas said he pulled Crawford once Wade (37 points) was on the bench for good. Wade checked out during a timeout with 6:52 left.  The Knicks led by 20 points heading into the fourth quarter. Crawford started the period by making a driving layup that got him to 48. After shooting an air ball from the arc, he struck from 12 feet and got his first standing ovation. He finished the night with a 22-footer with 6:59 left.  Crawford skipped to the bench during a timeout at 6:52 and was mobbed by Stephon Marbury, Quentin Richardson, David Lee and Nate Robinson. Thomas left him in for one more possession, and had Crawford foul Michael Doleac to stop the game and give the fans a chance for one more standing ovation. He left for good with 6:51 left.  ''He did it very classy, because we still had seven minutes to go,'' Crawford said of Thomas. ''I appreciated that.''  During the third quarter, Thomas gave Crawford his best advice.  ''I told him not to get around too many people and just try to stay balanced and stay focused and stay in the quiet, peaceful place that you're at right now,'' Thomas said.  The last Knick to score 50 points in a game, the retired Allan Houston, watched the show from a courtside seat. ''I was fortunate I could be here for that. It was amazing to see,'' Houston said.  Crawford was a picture of humility, crediting his teammates for unselfish passes and screens and Thomas for calling great plays.  The only hint of cockiness came late in the streak, between field goals 15 and 16. With the crowd chanting, ''Lets go, Crawford,'' he jogged upcourt, glanced at the press table and winked.  ''Unbelievable performance,'' said Wade. ''I have never seen anything like that before. The guy was hot.''  The Heat had a 41-40 lead in the second quarter when Crawford began his run. He scored the Knicks' next 10 points. The Knicks finished the half on a 25-8 run, with Crawford providing 17 points and giving them a 65-49 lead at halftime. The Knicks sealed the game with an 11-0 run to open the second half, with Crawford providing 7 of the points.  Crawford missed his first four shots of the game before starting the streak. He started in place of the slumping Jared Jeffries. Thomas said he wanted more offense on the court but would not say whether the move was permanent.  O'Neal, who returned to the Heat's rotation on Wednesday, after a two-month absence, started the game in place of Alonzo Mourning, who was ill. O'Neal, still regaining his stamina after knee surgery, played just 15 minutes and finished with 11 points.  Marbury, who missed the Knicks' last six quarters because of a sore left knee, was steady in his return, with 9 points and a season-high 13 assists.  REBOUNDS  The worst moment of Nate Robinson's NBA career will not prevent him from repeating his best moment. The league has invited Robinson to defend his slam-dunk title next month at All-Star weekend. Robinson had feared he might be denied that chance because he instigated the Dec. 16 brawl with Denver. Robinson served a 10-game suspension. ''I'm ecstatic,'' he said of defending his title. Regarding the fight and its effect on his image, Robinson said, ''That's behind me, what happened.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: With 52 Points, Crawford Steals the Show

content.text: Disaster took on many forms for the Knicks on Monday night. Had a 28-point first-quarter deficit been the worst of it, they might have left South Florida feeling grateful.  They had greater concerns, however, after being routed, 101-83, by the star-depleted Miami Heat at American Airlines Arena. Stephon Marbury's left knee again became too painful to bear, and he played only 15 minutes 58 seconds before leaving the game for good. His status for Wednesday's home game against the Phoenix Suns is uncertain.  Marbury, who routinely plays hurt and nearly always vows to be back by the next game, could not make that declaration this time.  ''I don't know yet,'' he said. ''To really be honest, I don't know.''  Had Marbury been at full strength, the Knicks (18-25) would have probably still been blown out by the energized Heat (19-22). Miami looked that determined. The Knicks looked that disoriented, at least in the first quarter.  After Quentin Richardson made a 3-pointer for a 3-2 lead, the Heat scored 27 consecutive points -- a Miami franchise record. The Knicks went 8:14 without scoring until Eddy Curry made a driving layup to cut the deficit to 29-5.  Coach Isiah Thomas called timeouts, to no avail. He sent in Jamal Crawford for Jared Jeffries and David Lee for Curry, and later sent in Nate Robinson and Malik Rose for Marbury and Channing Frye. The Heat kept scoring, and the Knicks kept missing.  ''It seems like the court's tilted, like they're running downhill, shooting layups and making 3's,'' Lee said. ''And we're going uphill just to get the ball across halfcourt and try to get a shot up.''  It was the kind of display one might expect when the defending champion plays one of the league's weaker teams. Except that the Heat was missing its two biggest stars -- Shaquille O'Neal and Dwyane Wade -- and the Knicks had lately appeared to be stronger than this.  Thomas was forced to concede the obvious, that the Knicks had perhaps been overconfident. ''Probably,'' he said.  Thomas had far worse things to say about his team.  ''This is the first time I've been with this group where we didn't show up to compete,'' he said. ''Maybe respect had something to do with it.''  The disbelief in Thomas's expression was matched by the exasperation in his players' voices. No one disputed the conclusions. They just could not fathom how it all happened.  ''We don't have the luxury of taking anybody lightly,'' Richardson said. ''We're not that good.''  Even without Wade (who has a sprained ankle) and O'Neal (who missed his 36th game after knee surgery), the Heat had a stockpile of talented and accomplished veterans: Alonzo Mourning, Gary Payton, Jason Williams and Udonis Haslem among them.  ''They performed flawlessly,'' said Ron Rothstein, the Heat's acting head coach while Pat Riley recovers from surgery.  With the ageless Mourning setting the tone, the Heat outrebounded the Knicks, 45-33. Mourning blocked four shots, including consecutive swats of Lee in the first quarter, and finished with seven rebounds.  Payton, who is also in his twilight, started for Wade and collected 10 points and 13 assists. Williams had 20 points and 7 assists. Jason Kapono scored 12 points in the first quarter -- matching the Knicks' team output -- and finished with 22.  The Knicks trailed by 40-12 at the end of the first quarter and were down by 15 points at halftime, when Marbury said he was done for the night.  Crawford (23 points) and Curry (26 points) led a second-half rally, and the Knicks cut their deficit to 6 points with 8:10 left in the game. They were down by just 8 points with 5:37 left, but Williams hit two 3-pointers and Antoine Walker followed with another 3-pointer to kill the Knicks' surge.  ''By the time we showed up, the game was over,'' Thomas said.  When all the self-flogging was over, the attention turned to Marbury's health. He has had trouble with the knee for more than a month, since banging the patellar tendon in a game Dec. 15 at Indiana. But Marbury has not missed a game this season and has not flinched at playing 40 minutes on many nights.  The knee had not been an issue until Saturday, when Marbury landed awkwardly late in the fourth quarter at Indiana. He spent the final 1:26 on the bench. On Monday morning, Marbury dismissed concerns about the knee, saying it had improved greatly after a therapeutic massage that broke up scar tissue.  But he passed up some early scoring opportunities and went to the bench for good with 4:51 left in the first half.  ''Just running on it, it just got really sore,'' he said. ''It's just going to take some time for it to heal a little bit.''  Asked if that meant he might have to take time off, Marbury said, ''I don't know, I'm just going to see.'' But, he reiterated, ''it's not something that I'm worried about.''  With Steve Francis still in Houston -- presumably rehabilitating his own sore knee -- the Knicks can ill afford to lose Marbury. There are no indications that Francis will return anytime soon, if he does at all. Last season, the Knicks went 5-17 in games that Marbury missed.  ''I don't even want to think that way, 5-17,'' Thomas said. ''I mean, that wouldn't be good right now.''  REBOUNDS  Isiah Thomas said he had no update on the status of Steve Francis, who left for Houston three weeks ago to rehabilitate a sore knee. Reminded that he had said he hoped Francis would return soon, Thomas said with a chuckle, ''I still hope that.'' ... The Heat's previous franchise record for consecutive points scored was 26, against the Golden State Warriors on March 24, 1995.  BASKETBALL
content.title: After Loss, Concerns About Effort, and Marbury's Knee

content.text: Charted on a line graph, the zigs and zags of Jamal Crawford's Knicks career would create one long and very jagged mountain range across the page. He zigs between starter and reserve and starter again. He zags from ace shooter to slumping shooter and back again.  The only constant in all of this is that somehow the ball always lands in Crawford's hands when the Knicks are at their most desperate and -- more often than not, it seems -- the ball is next seen swishing through the net.  So there was nothing particularly surprising about yesterday's events: Crawford is pushed back to bench, Crawford misfires all game, Crawford scores winning basket. The script was familiar to the point of predictability as the Knicks rode Crawford's late surge to a 102-97 victory against the Sacramento Kings at Madison Square Garden.  ''He does it too much,'' Eddy Curry said wryly of Crawford, his teammate and close friend. ''It's kind of boring to me.''  The Garden crowd has seen this script before too, but the 19,207 who attended the Martin Luther King's Birthday matinee were sufficiently entertained.  The Knicks (17-22) won for the fifth time in their past six home games and did so with a dramatic flourish.  They won despite another shaky defensive effort, allowing Kevin Martin to collect 30 points and Shareef Abdur-Rahim -- whose days as a big-time scorer ended a few years ago -- to score 25. The Kings shot nearly 50 percent through three quarters and had a 97-96 lead with 26.2 seconds left.  Cue Crawford. Dribbling near the top of the key, Crawford blew by Martin and converted a short runner in the lane, giving the Knicks the lead with 18.3 seconds left. The Kings turned the ball over when Corliss Williamson set an illegal screen on Stephon Marbury.  Crawford sealed the victory with four free throws in the last 13.8 seconds.  The day began with Coach Isiah Thomas inserting Quentin Richardson into the starting lineup. Crawford, who had started the previous 17 games, went back to the bench, where he began the season. But Thomas never gave a thought to changing Crawford's fourth-quarter role.  ''I think it's pretty understood on our team that the last couple minutes of the game, we depend on him to make a lot of big shots,'' Thomas said. ''The great thing about him at the end of the game is his temperament, that if he misses a shot or makes a mistake, the next day you see the same Jamal in practice and you see the same personality and the same temperament.''  That has pretty much been the story of Crawford's three-year run in New York. He has played 188 games as a Knick, 115 of them as a starter. Even on Sunday, as Thomas pondered the lineup change, Crawford played both roles, wearing a white jersey for part of practice, then turning it inside out, to the blue side.  Late yesterday afternoon, he wore an aw-shucks smile as someone observed that his role has fluctuated.  ''To say the least,'' Crawford said, chuckling. ''At this point, I've kind of gotten used to it. Of course you'd love to start, but I can't complain, because I'm still out there at the end of games.''  It was a typically serene response, one Crawford has had ample time to practice. His performance yesterday was also typical. He shot 1 for 8 in the first three quarters but 2 for 3 in the fourth, when he scored 8 of his 10 points. He also had eight assists, tied with Marbury for the team lead.  Crawford said Thomas discussed the lineup change with him Sunday.  ''Both of us had input, and I have a lot of respect for him for that,'' said Crawford, who said he gave the usual response: ''That I'll do what's best for the team.''  The scoring load was shared by Marbury (25 points) and Curry (24 points, 10 rebounds). Channing Frye added 17 points, and a resurgent David Lee had 15 points and 12 rebounds. Richardson, making his first start since returning from a back injury, had 7 points and 5 assists.  Ron Artest, a Queens native who burned the Knicks for 39 points in Sacramento two weeks ago, scored only 12 points. His first shot of the game was blocked by Jared Jeffries, and his last shot was an errant 3-point attempt that could have tied the score in the final 10 seconds.  Jeffries, Richardson, Lee, Crawford and Renaldo Balkman spent time guarding Artest yesterday. But the key defensive move came early in the fourth quarter, when Marbury began to guard Martin. Marbury made the move on his own and held Martin to one 3-pointer.  REBOUNDS  Isiah Thomas said he spoke recently with Steve Francis but offered no update on Francis' health. ''I don't try to keep track of it day to day,'' Thomas said. Francis has been rehabilitating his sore right knee in Houston for the past two weeks. Thomas and Francis' agent have denied reports that they are negotiating a contract buyout.  Nate Robinson did not play yesterday and has logged only 18 minutes in three games since returning from his suspension. ''We won today, I'm happy,'' Robinson said. Thomas said the decision was based on matchups. ''Nate's a very important piece to the puzzle, and we need him,'' Thomas said.  Quentin Richardson made his first start at shooting guard, giving the Knicks their ninth lineup of the season. Richardson had started 24 games at small forward.  Kings center Brad Miller missed the game because of personal reasons.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Crawford's Typical Day Ends in Knicks Victory

content.text: The Nets' success was clear and emphatic Monday.  Jason Kidd, the 33-year-old captain, fell one rebound short of his 83rd career triple-double. Vince Carter made it look easy, scoring 31 points. The journeyman center Mikki Moore blocked a shot and then yelled so loudly and scowled so fiercely that he seemed to rattle a young girl sitting in the first row at Continental Arena.  Leading by as many as 27 points against the Indiana Pacers, the Nets won for the sixth time in their last eight games, 105-95. The game followed a disappointing defeat at Minnesota on Saturday night, when the Nets fell apart in the fourth quarter.  Weeks ago, such a deflating defeat would have probably sent the Nets (17-20) into a slide. But now they carry themselves with a winning swagger.  ''I think we've been competing at a high level in the sense of as a team,'' said Kidd, who had 19 points, 10 assists and 9 rebounds. ''It's not been just one person playing. I think everybody's been pitching in.''  The most unheralded contributor during the Nets' turnaround has been Moore. He replaced Nenad Krstic, who tore his anterior cruciate ligament last month.  Moore, acquired last summer from the Seattle SuperSonics for a second-round pick, has exceeded expectations as an off-the-bench energy player. Although he cannot recall being a first option on offense, Moore has been scoring at an unusual pace.  Moore scored 19 points Monday, the third time this season that he has matched or surpassed his previous career high, 18.  ''I'm having a good time out there,'' he said. ''The team is real unselfish, man. If the play is there for me to get the ball, they make sure I get the ball. If they're going to put that much trust in me, I've got to finish.''  Moore, who made his first four field-goal attempts, all dunks, made his biggest mark on defense in the third quarter. He swatted a layup attempt by Pacers center Jermaine O'Neal, screamed, flexed and stared ahead.  ''Anybody can score, but once you get a stop, once you make a team do what they don't want to do, you can make offensive runs,'' Moore said. ''You can make transition baskets easy off of defense.''  The Nets' offense was precise in the first quarter -- eight straight field goals over one stretch -- and late in the period, Kidd scored 7 consecutive points. The first 2 points came on a smart play in which he intercepted an outlet pass by Al Harrington, who led the Pacers with 18 points, and then drove for an easy layup.  He followed with a 16-foot bank shot over Jamaal Tinsley, and after making a free throw, he hit a fadeaway jumper to give the Nets their first double-digit lead of the game, 29-18, with 3 minutes 35 seconds to play in the quarter.  The Nets steadily pulled away in the second quarter, building a 21-point lead at halftime. They led by as many as 27 points in the third quarter. Through three quarters, the Nets were shooting 50.8 percent from the field and they held the Pacers (20-18) to 37.9 percent shooting. The statistics were skewed by the fact that the Nets entered the fourth quarter with a 25-point lead and were not at their sharpest.  Since filing for divorce last week, Kidd has been playing some of his best basketball of the season. By all indications, he has appeared as happy as ever during practices and games.  ''I think you could make the argument he is having as good a year as he's ever had,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''I think any time it is called into question that he is not where he was, that just fuels the fire, and that's what the great ones do.''  Kidd may be looking to add to his legacy. He addressed a report that he would be invited to join the United States national basketball team.  ''If that's the case, I would love to be a part of that team this summer to help try to regain that special feeling of winning in international ball,'' he said.  REBOUNDS  Marcus Williams, the Nets' rookie point guard, returned after a two-game absence because of strep throat, which left him bedridden for four days. Williams finished with 6 points, 3 rebounds and an assist in 11 minutes.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Get Unexpected Lift From Moore on Offense

content.text: After two years of waiting and not much playing, Serena Williams is back in a final, and it happens to be in a Grand Slam tournament.  Williams continued the most surprising run of her career Thursday by defeating the 17-year-old Czech Nicole Vaidisova, 7-6 (5), 6-4, in the semifinals of the Australian Open, which she won in 2003 and 2005.  In 2003, Williams was the overwhelming favorite, having won the three previous Grand Slam tournaments. In 2005, she was still on the short list of contenders. This year, she was a true underdog, arriving here with a world ranking of 81, having played in only five tournaments in the last year.  Now, after beating five seeded players, including the 10th-seeded Vaidisova, she has put herself back at the center of the sport and guaranteed herself a place in the top 20.  ''I can't believe it; that's awesome,'' said Williams, whooping it up on court in her postmatch interview. ''That was so fast.''  Speedy indeed, but it took her more time than she would have liked to close out the powerful but erratic Vaidisova, a 6-foot blonde who left Europe to train at Nick Bollettieri's Tennis Academy in Bradenton, Fla., as a youngster, occasionally sneaking peeks at Williams's training sessions there.  Down by 1-5 in the second set, Vaidisova closed the gap to 4-5, saving five match points, before Williams finally closed out the 1-hour, 46-minute victory with a forehand volley winner.  Williams will face the winner of Thursday's second semifinal between top-seeded Maria Sharapova of Russia and No. 4 Kim Clijsters of Belgium, neither of whom has won this title.  As Williams walked through the corridors of Rod Laver Arena, minutes before walking on court, she saw her agent, Jill Smoller, who greeted her by clenching her fists and striking a muscle-beach pose and then giving her a roundhouse smack on the rear.  It was a sign of what makes Williams tick. This surprising run in Melbourne has been much more about desire than thorough preparation, much more about muscle memory and competitiveness than hard-won fitness.  Once on court against Vaidisova, it took time for Williams to bare her teeth. Despite the power being produced on both ends of the court, the pace was slow, almost reflective between the points, and the early games were long.  Vaidisova's game plan was clear early: attack Williams's second serves and try to move her -- not just side to side but back to front with the occasional drop shot. At the start, Vaidisova applied these principles well, breaking Williams's serve in the opening game after two deuces and then holding her own serve to go up, 2-0.  But Williams, who looked sluggish at times early, began moving and serving more convincingly -- she would finish with 10 aces -- and adjusting to Vaidisova's big returns.  Vaidisova, taking huge risks, began to produce more errors than winners with her forehand, with its huge backswing and relatively low margin for error. Williams broke her in the sixth game to get back on serve, but Vaidisova would still get her chance to win the set when she broke Williams again to go up, 5-4, and then served for the lead.  After saving a break point with an ace to get to deuce, she failed to put another first serve into play in the game, as Williams saved a set point with a big forehand that Vaidisova could not handle. It was soon 5-5 and then 6-6, with Williams jumping out to a 5-1 lead in the tie breaker and then holding on to win the set after Vaidisova rallied to 5-5, with Williams serving consecutive double faults at 5-2..  Vaidisova's pride and power in the tie breaker was foreshadowing for the second set when, apparently out of contention, she roared back, saving four match points on her serve at 3-5 and another on Williams's serve at 4-5 before she closed it out.  ''Almost did a gagarooni there,'' Williams said. ''Basically that means gagging. But she played some incredible points on match points, just got relaxed. She reminded me a little bit of myself.''  In late matches on Wednesday, Tommy Haas and Fernando González took radically different paths to their upset victories.  Haas had to win arguments with himself as well as win rallies, and had to fight through rough patches, swooping pigeons and even a match point before finally closing out Nikolay Davydenko of Russia, the world's third-ranked player, in five sets.  González, once again, could do little wrong, coming up with clutch serves and huge forehands on points big and small. He also kept the unforced errors that were once his trademarks to a minimum as he overwhelmed Rafael Nadal of Spain, the second-ranked player, in straight sets.  Though their methods and moods were disparate, the 10th-seeded González and the 12th-seeded Haas share a healthy perspective. They are both middle-aged for tennis stars -- Haas is a 28-year-old German, González a 26-year-old Chilean -- and both have had to wait their turn for the sort of breakthrough that prodigies like Nadal understandably take for granted.  Now these two flashy players with one-handed backhands will share the spotlight with each other in the semifinals Friday night at Rod Laver Arena. In the other semifinal, top-seeded Roger Federer was to face Andy Roddick on Thursday. Sharapova, seeded No. 1, and Clijsters, seeded fourth, both struggled yet prevailed on Wednesday. Clijsters, who has announced that this will be her last Australian Open, failed to control her power for significant stretches of the first and second sets, finishing with 62 unforced errors and 47 winners against the three-time champion Martina Hingis.  The last time Haas was in the final four of a Grand Slam was here in 2002, the same year he topped out at No. 2 in the rankings, the same year his right shoulder failed him, requiring two surgeries and knocking him out of the game for more than a year and out of contention for the major prizes until now.  Haas was the only man to push Federer to a fifth set in any Grand Slam last year, doing so here in the fourth round. He later lost to Davydenko in five sets in the quarterfinals of the United States Open, paying the toll for the two five-set victories that preceded the match.  He could have gone down swinging again this time if Davydenko had managed to return Haas's kicking second serve on his one and only match point at 4-5, 30-40 in the fifth set. But Davydenko went for too much and missed a backhand into the net.  Haas missed his first chance to close out the match when serving at 6-5, 40-15 when Davydenko successfully challenged a line call on a forehand that had been called out. But Haas converted on his next match point, moving to his left and hitting his signature running backhand down the line. That left the baseline-hugging Davydenko, usually the master of the full-swinging half volley, to lunge and miss as Haas won, 6-3, 2-6, 1-6, 6-1, 7-5.  González has become a familiar presence in the second week of Grand Slam events, but only early in the second week. He reached the quarterfinals at the 2002 United States Open, the quarterfinals of the 2003 French Open and even the quarterfinals in 2005 at Wimbledon.  But it has taken until now for the huge-hitting, soft-spoken González to take the next step into the semifinals, and he has done so in great style despite a meaty draw that required him to face Lleyton Hewitt in the third round and the supposedly red-hot James Blake in the fourth. Then came Nadal, the tenacious left-hander.  ''I'm delighted, but it's not over,'' González said after his 6-2, 6-4, 6-3 victory in which he never lost his serve, finishing with 41 winners, including 10 aces, and just 16 unforced errors.  Nadal has been the best player not named Roger Federer for the last two seasons, but he was not at his best Wednesday, finishing with seven more unforced errors than winners and failing to play the same sort of spectacularly effective defense that, along with his whipping forehand and combativeness, has defined him.  The reasons, according to Nadal, were González and the aftershocks of his marathon match with Andy Murray in the fourth round: a late-night five-setter that left him feeling soreness in his legs and pain in his upper left leg.  ''It was taking a lot of effort for me to run; I couldn't keep up with the rhythm of the match,'' Nadal said.  TENNIS
content.title: A Strong Run Leads Williams To the Finals In Australia

content.text: The first man into the quarterfinals of this year's Australian Open on Sunday was unseeded Mardy Fish, which was quite an achievement considering the former state of his forehand and his left wrist.  But Fish, long considered a talented yet unreliable player, has managed to recover from both those handicaps in the last two years with the help of two operations on his wrist and of his coaches Scott Humphries and Todd Martin, each a former Tour player.  Now Fish, 25, is in the final eight at a Grand Slam event for the first time, and, as the luck of the draw would have it, the man he will face is his childhood housemate Andy Roddick.  ''We were more like brothers than best friends,'' Fish said of the years he spent living with the Roddick family in Florida when he and Roddick were aspiring juniors.  Fish advanced Sunday with a 6-1, 7-6 (4), 2-6, 7-5 victory over 16th-seeded David Ferrer of Spain, who had beaten Fish in their two previous matches. Roddick advanced with another impressive performance under heavy pressure, winning by 6-3, 3-6, 6-1, 5-7, 6-4 against the net-rushing Mario Ancic of Croatia.  ''I knew in the fifth set, win or lose, I had to try to turn the tables on the aggression,'' said Roddick, who broke the ninth-seeded Ancic in the fifth game of the final set, then held that advantage, serving out the match in style and winning it with a backhand winner down the line.  That shot was a symbol of Roddick's revival in the last six months with the help of his new coach, Jimmy Connors, whose two-handed backhand was his signature shot. Connors was in the front row of Rod Laver Arena on Sunday, pounding on the wall as the sixth-seeded Roddick again came up with the clutch shots he required, just as he had in his third-round bout with the former Australian Open champion Marat Safin.  A year ago, in the fourth round on this same court, Roddick, erratic and confused, was upset by Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus in four sets. This year, despite Ancic's constant pressure, Roddick passed the test and is now a heavy favorite to reach the semifinals in light of his current form and a 4-1 record against Fish.  ''It's always a little weird when we play each other because of our history,'' Roddick said.  In the fourth round, the Scottish teenager Andy Murray will have his dream matchup at the Australian Open, but it is not so certain that James Blake has his. Murray had been eagerly awaiting his first chance to match his fluid and fast-maturing all-court game against the slashing forehand and athleticism of Rafael Nadal, the leader of Murray's generation.  Murray granted his own wish by winning in straight sets, 6-3, 6-2, 6-4, against Juan Ignacio Chela of Argentina on Saturday. Chela overwhelmed Murray in the first round here last year.  But there will be no novelty for Blake when he faces Fernando González of Chile in the fourth round. They have played six times, and González has won the past three matches, all on quick surfaces.  ''He's given me problems the last few times, but I've had some success against him earlier in his career,'' Blake said. ''Hopefully, I can draw on that and get back to the winning ways against him. He's playing pretty confident right now as well.''  On Saturday, against his close friend Robby Ginepri, Blake had to save a set point in the first set, then saved four more set points in the second with Ginepri serving at 5-4. What will look like a straightforward 7-6 (7), 7-5, 6-2 victory on the draw sheet was hardly that.  Ginepri spent time around more than your average weekend hacker in the off-season, playing the latest of a series of exhibition matches against the retired Pete Sampras. ''He taught me a thing or two,'' said Ginepri, who added that Sampras had been thinking about playing one more Wimbledon.  ''There's been some talk about it, but you never know with that,'' Ginepri said. ''He left the sport in a magical way, so he wouldn't want to ruin that.''  TENNIS
content.title: Fish, Into Quarterfinals, Will Face Ex-Housemate

content.text: Ivory Latta shook her fists and shuddered as the roar from the near-sellout crowd drowned out the players on the floor of Carmichael Auditorium on Monday night. Latta, a compact jitterbug and the leader of North Carolina's women's basketball team, had just swished a tie-breaking 3-pointer from the top of the key with 1 minute 1 second remaining against Connecticut in a battle of two of the best teams in the country.  On this night, No. 2-ranked North Carolina was just a little bit better.  The Tar Heels squandered a 15-point lead in the second half, but came back for an 82-76 victory to extend their season-opening winning streak to 20 games and remain one of two undefeated teams in the country. Rival Duke (19-0) is the other.  North Carolina forward Erlana Larkins finished with 15 points and 16 rebounds; LaToya Pringle contributed 18 points; and Latta added 14 but had 8 turnovers.  Kalana Greene led Connecticut (14-2) with 23 points.  North Carolina has now beaten Connecticut three years in a row, including a 77-54 victory in Hartford last season that was the worst defeat in Coach Geno Auriemma's 21 years at UConn.  The Tar Heels have defeated two of the most storied programs in the country this season, including an earlier victory against Tennessee.  ''Both Connecticut and Tennessee to me, those teams are measuring sticks,'' North Carolina Coach Sylvia Hatchell said. ''They have for years been at the top of women's basketball. For us to have had wins this year against those two, that means a lot to me because I think those two programs have set the bar for a long time.''  UConn lost to No. 4 Tennessee by 70-64 on Jan. 6; the Lady Vols squandered an 18-point lead before rallying to hand the No. 6 Huskies their first defeat of the season.  ''If I was a smarter guy, if I was a more realistic guy, I would have said, 'Well, you know, those are the growing pains that young teams go through,' '' Auriemma said. ''But this is Connecticut basketball and you don't play at Connecticut and go through growing pains. You come to Connecticut grown up. We can talk all we want about the effort and the courage it took to come back. The bottom line is, at Connecticut the only time you're happy is when you win.''  The Huskies nearly pulled it off. The Tar Heels led through most of the game and pulled ahead by 60-45 with 13:15 remaining in the second half. But foul trouble proved costly for North Carolina.  Larkins had picked up her fourth foul moments earlier and was sent to the bench. Without her presence under the basket on both ends, Connecticut was able to chip away at the lead. Larkins stayed on the bench as the Huskies used an 11-0 run to close to 64-62 with 7:00 to go. Larkins returned after that, setting up a furious finish.  Connecticut finally took its first lead when guard Renee Montgomery scored with 4:51 remaining to put the Huskies ahead, 70-68. The teams went back and forth after that for nearly four minutes with neither able to pull away. But Latta's 3-point shot broke a 76-76 tie and Connecticut could not answer. Latta added two free throws to seal the victory.  Perhaps this triumph will nudge North Carolina to No. 1 next week. The Tar Heels were No. 2 last week when the top team, Maryland, lost to No. 3 Duke on Saturday. Instead of moving up, North Carolina stayed at No. 2 while Duke leapfrogged to the top spot.  Hatchell made sure to mention it to the team at halftime as a motivator.  Larkins said, ''It in a sense doesn't really matter what other people think of us as long as we know that in our heart we have a chance to be the No. 1 team and we are the No. 1 team.''  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: Tar Heels Rally to Top Huskies And Extend Win Streak to 20

content.text: After running through the gamut of emotions, from the highest highs late last week to another stupefying low Sunday afternoon, the Knicks were left with a bad case of whiplash.  Then again, the condition might simply have been a product of watching their shots fly in the opposite direction. The Knicks converted a season-low 34.5 percent of their field-goals attempts Sunday, in large part because 16 of their attempts were swatted away by the Los Angeles Clippers, who cruised to a 90-80 victory at the Staples Center.  Elton Brand accounted for eight of those blocks, a career high, and scored an efficient 32 points to ruin the Knicks' New Year's Eve. The defeat denied the Knicks (13-20) a chance to claim a share of first place in the Atlantic Division. It prevented them from recording a .500 record in December, leaving them 7-9. And, combined with Friday night's lopsided loss in Phoenix, it wiped out all the exhilaration of the previous two weeks. That triple-overtime victory last week against Detroit already seems like a distant memory.  ''I'd be lying if I told you I wasn't frustrated right now,'' forward David Lee said. ''All our guys are frustrated.''  The Knicks trailed wire to wire, by as many as 24 points, and never got closer than 10 in the second half. They also trailed by as many as 24 points in Phoenix, where they never got closer than 11. But the Clippers (14-16) are not the Suns, and Coach Isiah Thomas surely expected his team to have learned something in Saturday's extensive film session here.  But there are lessons that still elude them and the most damaging one is how to keep the offense rolling when Eddy Curry is double-teamed. The Clippers, like the Suns, crowded Curry every time he touched the ball. Curry made 5 of 13 shots, and six of his seven misses were blocked. He finished with 15 points.  ''It seemed like they were coming from everywhere tonight,'' Curry said.  The Knicks do not have the shooters to keep defenses honest. Indeed, their forward rotation is littered with players who have no reliable jump shot -- Lee, Jared Jeffries and Renaldo Balkman. Jeffries played just 15 minutes Sunday.  ''I don't think it's Eddy's fault, whatsoever,'' Lee said. ''He's getting double-teamed and guys need to step up and make a play, myself included.''  It would help to have the injured Quentin Richardson back. But the Knicks also need Curry to take the next step as a franchise player, and diversify his game.  ''It's just different because of how they're guarding Eddy now,'' Stephon Marbury said. ''Once Eddy understands that he's going to be double-teamed for the remainder of his career, it's going to be tough for us until he understands that. He's starting to learn that when the trap comes to kick it out right away and repost. This is all brand new to him.''  Thomas tried everything Sunday -- playing Curry and Jerome James as co-centers, benching Jeffries for long stretches, and leaning hard on the rookie Mardy Collins. Curry and Jamal Crawford were on the bench in the fourth quarter when a unit featuring James, Collins, Lee, Marbury and Channing Frye cut a 24-point deficit to 84-74 with 3 minutes 36 seconds to play. The Clippers responded with three quick baskets.  ''I was just searching, pushing every button I could push tonight,'' Thomas said. ''And I finally got a group out there that had some semblance of working together and I just tried to stick with it.''  While Richardson missed his eighth game in a row because of back spasms, the Knicks' guards had another terrible shooting performance. Crawford was 2 for 8 and Marbury 3 for 13.
