Collins, in his first game back from a suspension, was the best shooter, hitting 4 of 9 shots, including three 3-pointers. He finished with a career-high 11 points and is likely to keep his rotation spot while Richardson and Steve Francis recover from injuries.  ''He was definitely a bright spot,'' Thomas said of Collins. ''I hope I can keep finding him minutes.''  For Collins, every game is a chance to make a name for himself. Until then, the image of him is as the guy who committed the flagrant foul that set off the brawl with Denver.  ''It's definitely tough to be known, the first thing you come in the league, to be known as a guy that's like this and like that,'' Collins said. ''So my whole thing is to try to go out there and prove to them and show them I can actually play basketball, try to forget about the whole situation.''  REBOUNDS  Steve Francis was back in a suit and tie Sunday afternoon, resting his right knee (tendinitis). Francis played sparingly last week, when the Knicks desperately needed another guard, but he was limited. ''I can't do anything,'' Francis said. ''It's constant pain at all times. I couldn't run or stop.''  Nate Robinson, barred from attending N.B.A. games during his suspension, went to the U.C.L.A.-Washington game at Pauley Pavilion. Robinson played three years for Washington before being drafted by the Knicks in 2005.  PRO BASKETBALL  Correction:  January 3, 2007, Wednesday  A sports article on Monday about the Knicks' 90-80 loss to the Clippers in Los Angeles misidentified the team that drafted guard Nate Robinson in 2005. It was the Phoenix Suns, who selected him at the Knicks' request, then traded him and Quentin Richardson to the Knicks for Kurt Thomas the same day; the Knicks did not draft Robinson.
content.title: Knicks Have a Hard Time Dealing With Rejection

content.text: The Boston Marathon scored a coup yesterday when it added Deena Kastor, the 33-year-old American who ran the world's fastest time for a woman last year, to its April 16 race, which is six days before the London Marathon. It will be Kastor's Boston debut.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: MARATHON
content.title: KASTOR TO RUN BOSTON

content.text: Isiah Thomas and Larry Brown will cross paths in a few days -- if not literally, then at least by proxy, via their respective teams. Less than seven months after being fired as the Knicks' coach, Brown was hired as an executive for the Philadelphia 76ers, who visit Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.  This odd bit of happenstance is well timed, with Thomas just hitting a critical juncture in his quest for ''significant progress'' -- a standard that specifically requires him to beat Brown's 23-59 record as coach last season.  Last week, the Knicks sank to 13-21, the same record they had under Brown one year ago. It was a bad sign for Thomas, who will be fired as coach and team president if the Knicks finish as miserably as they did last season.  But the intersection of won-lost records was temporary. Thomas pulled ahead in the virtual race with two big victories to finish the week, and it is probable that his winning percentage is about to spike upward.  The Knicks (15-21) have completed the toughest portion of their schedule and have survived their toughest test -- playing with a depleted roster for the past four weeks. They remain in contention for the Atlantic Division title and the playoff berth that comes with it.  Two important players, Quentin Richardson and Nate Robinson, are set to return Wednesday. If ever the Knicks appeared primed for a resurgence, it is now.  ''I'm hoping that's the case,'' Thomas said Friday night, after a 111-93 rout of the SuperSonics in Seattle. That victory came on the heels of a 99-81 defeat of Portland and gave the Knicks a 6-4 record since their brawl with Denver.  ''We're starting to play good basketball,'' Thomas said. ''I just like our attitude and our approach to things. I like our temperament, the toughness that we're playing with mentally.''  Thomas would not forecast a .500 record or a playoff run. But both appear possible.  The Knicks packed a league-high 36 games in the first 66 days of the season. They now downshift, with 46 games spread over the last 102 days. Half of those games will be on the road, but most of them are one-game trips -- and two are in New Jersey. The Knicks' longest remaining trip is three games.  They have only five road games remaining against the superior Western Conference. Thirty-one of their final 46 games are against the Eastern Conference. They have 11 games against their own division, which is the lowest number in the league.  After initially struggling at home, the Knicks have won four games in a row at the Garden, and five of their past six. And after going 5-11 to start the season, the Knicks have gone 10-10 since Nov. 28.  At this time last year, the Knicks had already peaked, with a six-game winning streak that got them to 13-21. They promptly collapsed. Stephon Marbury was lost to a shoulder injury, and the Knicks dropped their next six games. They also had losing streaks of 10 games, 6, 9 and 5 over the final three months under Brown.  Under Thomas, the Knicks have been more resilient. They have yet to lose more than three games in a row, despite losing a string of key players -- Richardson, Robinson, Channing Frye, Jared Jeffries and Steve Francis -- to injuries or suspensions.  The most striking difference from last season, however -- and the one that should make the greatest difference in the final months -- is the emergence of center Eddy Curry as the focal point of the offense.  In his last three games, Curry has scored 73 points on 27-of-35 shooting. His .771 shooting percentage is the N.B.A.'s highest over a three-game span, among players with at least 35 attempts, since San Antonio's David Robinson shot .800 (32 of 40) in January 1998.  The Knicks are 10-8 when Curry scores at least 20 points and have won the last six games when he has hit that mark. They are 6-2 when Curry scores 25 or more points. There is no longer any ambiguity in the game plan each night. Opponents are now forced to double-team Curry in the post, creating opportunities for everyone else. After initially struggling to adapt, Curry learned to make quicker passes and quicker moves. And he will be the greatest beneficiary when Richardson, the Knicks' best 3-point shooter, returns Wednesday.  ''It's a different game when teams have to double-team him,'' Jamal Crawford said of Curry. ''He gets the credit for changing the game for us.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Things Looking Up For Knicks And Coach

content.text: The banner hanging above the Notre Dame basketball team's bench shows that the last time the Irish reached the N.C.A.A. tournament was in 2003. Since then, Notre Dame has endured a long string of close calls, cruel losses and trips to the National Invitation Tournament.  ''So much heartbreak in so little time,'' said Russell Carter, one of the team's two seniors on scholarship. ''No one can really say they've had that kind of concentrated heartbreak.''  But in a season in which Notre Dame was picked to finish 11th in the Big East and given little chance of reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament, the No. 22 Irish have emerged as one of the biggest surprises in college basketball.  They have done so by overcoming their arch nemesis -- the close game. The Irish pulled out an improbable 66-63 victory against Villanova on Saturday, overcoming a 7-point deficit in the final seven minutes with Carter, their leading scorer, on the bench.  Villanova (14-6, 3-4 Big East) had two chances in the final 10 seconds that could have tied the score. But Reggie Redding's 26-foot heave from the right wing and Curtis Sumpter's contested look from the left side each caromed away.  ''I think this was a big step forward for us psychologically,'' Irish Coach Mike Brey said. ''For us to have to scratch and claw and grind. We haven't had to do that against a good team here.''  The senior swingman Colin Falls led the Irish with 23 points, including the game's most important basket, which capped off the game's defining sequence.  Notre Dame led by 2 points with just over a minute remaining when Irish forward Luke Harangody launched his 6-foot-8, 250-pound frame on the floor near midcourt to dislodge a ball from Villanova guard Scottie Reynolds. (In the stands, the play drew a smile of recognition from Charlie Weis, Notre Dame's football coach.)  Falls picked up Harangody's tip near midcourt and coasted in for a layup that gave Notre Dame a 64-60 lead with 1 minute 5 seconds remaining.  ''That was the play of the game,'' Brey said of Harangody's dive to force the turnover.  Notre Dame has been able to overcome the demons of the past three seasons thanks to the strong leadership of Falls and Carter, and the efforts of young players who haven't experienced the heartbreak endured by the seniors.  Three years ago, the Irish barely missed the N.C.A.A. tournament; they wound up looking back in regret and pinpointing an early-season loss to Central Michigan. The next season, the Irish were left out of the tournament after losing to a struggling Rutgers team in the first round of the Big East tournament. The game came a week after the Irish blew out the Scarlet Knights at home, but the star guard Chris Quinn was hurt in the game's first five minutes.  Last season, Notre Dame lost five games in overtime, done in time after time in the final seconds by other Big East teams.  ''I've really seen everything but the N.C.A.A. tournament,'' Falls said. ''I've seen huge conference wins. Huge nonconference wins. I've seen a lot of letdowns, a lot of disappointments.  ''I've had the highs and lows.''  The highs on Saturday came thanks in part to the sophomore swingman Ryan Ayers, who drained a 3-pointer from the left wing to tie the score at 60-60 with 2:29 left.  Ayers has joined Harangody and the freshman point guard Tory Jackson, who had only one turnover in 36 minutes, in the youth movement that has helped the Irish exorcise their bad memories.  Notre Dame's record (17-4, 5-3 Big East) and out-of-conference victories over Maryland and Alabama have the Irish poised to see the star-crossed careers of Falls and Carter end in the N.C.A.A. tournament.  ''That's what's driving me,'' Brey said. ''I want to coach those guys in the N.C.A.A. tournament.''  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: With Leading Scorer on Bench, Irish Help Erase Cruel Memories

content.text: Eddy Curry found perfection Friday night, Jamal Crawford had a happy homecoming and the Knicks transformed a once-miserable trip into a modest sign of hope for the coming months.  They closed their five-game trip through the West with a 111-93 rout of the Seattle SuperSonics at KeyArena, turning an 0-3 start into a 2-3 finish. Beating Portland and Seattle will not catapult the Knicks to the top of any power rankings, but it salvaged the trip and allowed them to keep hovering near the top of the Atlantic Division.  It is the way the Knicks finished that carried the most promise. Curry had 27 points in 30 minutes Friday, converting all nine of his field-goal attempts and 9 of 12 free throws. Crawford had 22 points in his hometown and Stephon Marbury scored 28 points.  By the Knicks' modest standards, the trip was a success.  ''If you win three, it's a great trip. If you win two, it's a good trip,'' Coach Isiah Thomas said before the game, adding, ''You definitely want to do better. You want to get close to .500 on the road.''  Playing against an undersized and largely inexperienced front line, Curry was at his dominating best. He had 15 points in the first quarter, scoring on reverse layups, dunks and at the foul line. His thunderous putback of a Channing Frye miss in the second quarter gave the Knicks a 48-37 lead, and his putback late in the second quarter gave them a 63-49 edge.  Seattle shrank from the challenge and the margin stayed in double digits the rest of the night, climbing as high as 24 points. The locals amused themselves in the final minutes by chanting ''We want Jerome,'' a reference to the Knicks backup Jerome James, who played here before joining the Knicks. The fans had booed him earlier in the evening.  Last season, this was the site of one of Crawford's most memorable performances -- 31 points, all in the second half of a 104-101 victory in his hometown. But Thomas had no expectations of a sequel. In fact, he anticipated the opposite.  ''I never think guys will play well when they come home,'' Thomas said. ''I always think that they'll go a little bit too far. I was no different. Whenever I went back to Chicago, sometimes I went a little bit too far. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't.''  Crawford had 50 friends and family members in the stands, and Thomas's worst fears materialized in the first half. Crawford fired early and often and without much conscience, missing 7 of his first 10 attempts. But he made his next three shots, including a 3-pointer that gave the Knicks a 61-46 lead.  They reached halftime with 68 points, the most they have scored in any half this season, and a 17-point lead.  Seattle was already having a miserable season, having lost the star forward Rashard Lewis to a hand injury Dec. 20. He is not expected back until late February. His absence leaves a heavy burden on Ray Allen, the Sonics sharpshooter, and when he struggles, Seattle cannot compete.  Stephon Marbury drew the initial assignment of guarding Allen, who never found his groove. Allen missed four of his first five shots and scored just 8 points in the first half.  Watching the game on television, with conflicting emotions, was Nate Robinson, the Knicks guard and Seattle native. His 10-game suspension for fighting ended at the final buzzer Friday, but any relief or joy was surely offset by the pain of missing the lone chance to play in his hometown.  But Robinson will be back in uniform when the Knicks play Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden. They will be as close to full strength as they have been all season, having survived the lengthy suspensions of Robinson, Jared Jeffries and Mardy Collins and recent injuries to Quentin Richardson, Steve Francis and Channing Frye.  With Friday's victory, the Knicks improved to 6-4 since the Denver brawl -- a far better winning rate than their 15-21 overall record.  ''When we get our whole team back, it's going to be trouble for people, period, in the N.B.A.,'' Robinson said. ''Seeing how they're playing and what they did in the triple-overtime game, it shows how much heart they have. And then with the energy that I'm going to bring back, hopefully that can put a spark in each guy.''  REBOUNDS  Coach Isiah Thomas will soon have a full roster and some tough decisions to make about the starting lineup and rotation. ''I look forward to having those decisions to make,'' Thomas said. The once-crowded rotation was simplified by a series of injuries and suspensions, but Thomas said, ''I'd rather have the weapons and the guns.''  Thomas seemed confident that Nate Robinson had learned a great life lesson during his 10-game suspension. ''I think it's given him a lot of time to reflect on his behavior, his attitude. In a funny kind of way, I think this may turn out to be a good thing for him,'' he said. Asked if Robinson would be a changed person, Thomas said: ''I think he'll try to be as best he can, but he's got a lot of energy that goes through that little body of his that makes him great. There are a lot of things that he can't help. There's a lot of things that that's just him. I keep emphasizing, when you're that small and you have that amount of energy flowing through your body, it's not like you can just sit down and be quiet.''  Quentin Richardson was held out of Friday's game but was expected to play Wednesday night against the Philadelphia 76ers. Richardson missed his 11th consecutive game, though he has recovered from back spasms. The Knicks decided to give Richardson four more days of rest, and a chance to practice.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Take Lead Early And Keep Adding to It
